What is the duration for which sperm stays in the epididymis?
questions.explanation:
Sperm Changes in epididymis

Description

Motility Acquisition
  • Sperm leaving the testes are not fully mobile.
  • They gain progressive motility in the epididymis.
  • Inhibitory proteins suppress motility until ejaculation.

Cation Channel Activation
  • Activation of CatSper family cation channels occurs. Alkaline-sensitive Ca2+ channels become active as sperm move to more alkaline cervical mucus.

Chemotaxis Development
  • Develop the ability to sense chemical signals from the ovaries, helping guide them toward the ovary.

Concentration
  • Become concentrated due to fluid reabsorption.

Epididymal Fluid Contribution
  • Epididymis and Sertoli cells secrete nutrient-rich fluid containing hormones, enzymes, and nutrients essential for maturation.

Sperm Storage
  • Epididymis serves as the primary storage site (for 2-4 weeks). (Option C)
  • Sperm can maintain fertility for at least a month.

Timeframe for Motility
  • Sperm gain the capability for motility after 18 to 24 hours in the epididymis.
  • Full maturation and hypermotility occur in the female genital tract.

Acrosome Maturation
  • The acrosome, located at the sperm head and containing enzymes for fertilization, matures while sperm are stored in the epididymis.

Zona Pellucida Binding Ability
  • Sperm acquire receptors during epididymal transit that enable them to bind to the zona pellucida, facilitating penetration and fertilization of the egg. Therefore this occurs before ejaculation.

Capacitation Post-Epididymis
  • Full fertilization capacity (capacitation) occurs after sperm leave the epididymis. This involves the removal of inhibitory factors and changes to the sperm membrane.

questions.text: In case a small pain stimulus causes more pain, it is called?
questions.explanation:
Criteria

Hyperalgesia (Option C)

Allodynia (Option D ruled out)

Definition

Severe pain from a stimulus that normally causes pain

Pain from a stimulus that normally wouldn't cause pain,

Sensitivity

Both increases sensitivity of nociceptive afferent fibers

Cause
  1. Primary hyperalgesia: Excessive sensitivity of the pain receptors.
    Eg : Extreme sensitivity of sunburned skin (results from sensitization of pain receptors due to local tissue products like histamine, prostaglandins)
     
  2. Secondary hyperalgesia: It is the facilitation of sensory transmission .
    Eg: Lesions in the spinal cord or thalamus

The exact cause is unknown. Likely involves error in neuronal conduction.

Eg:Painful sensation from a light touch which is never painful

Association

Both types of pain is seen in neuropathic pain and causalgia (severe burning pain in a specific part of the body) (Option B ruled out)

Function

 

Ventral Posterolateral (VPL) (Option C ruled out)

Relays somatosensory information from the body to the primary somatosensory cortex

 

Ventral Posteromedial (VPM) (Option B ruled out)

Relays somatosensory information from the face to the primary somatosensory cortex

Lateral Geniculate (LGN)

Relays visual information from the optic tracts to the primary visual cortex

Medial Geniculate (MGN)

Relays auditory information from the inferior colliculus to the primary auditory cortex

Ventral Anterior (VA)

Ventral Lateral (VL) (Option A)

Contributes to motor control by receiving input from the cerebellum

Anterior (AN)

Involved in memory, emotion, and regulation of the limbic system

Intralaminar Nuclei

Involved in arousal, attention, and modulation of pain perception

options.text: Anterior dislocation of hip with femoral artery injury

questions.explanation:
Posterior dislocation of hip

Anterior dislocation of hip

Central dislocation of hip

Mechanism of injury:
Caused by force along the femoral shaft with the hip flexed (e.g., dashboard injury in motor accidents).

Mechanism of injury:

Rare injury that occurs with forced abduction and external rotation.

Mechanism of injury:

The femoral head is driven through the medial wall of the acetabulum into the pelvic cavity.

Clinical Features:

  • History of trauma.
  • Pain, swelling.
  • Deformity: flexion, adduction, internal rotation.
  • Shortening of the leg.
  • The femoral head is palpable in the gluteal region.

Clinical features:

  • The limb appears externally rotated.
  • Possible lengthening of the affected limb
  • The femoral head is palpable in the groin.

 

Clinical features:

  • Varying displacement is seen.
  • Joint stiffness and osteoarthritis are very likely.
  • Nerve injury: common, sciatic nerve is injured.
  • Arterial injury: rare
  • Nerve injury: rare

questions.text: What will be the diagnosis of the following image of a 1-year old infant’s hand?
questions.explanation:
Simple Syndactyly

Only soft tissue is fused

Complex Syndactyly

Both skin and bone are fused

Complete Syndactyly

Webbing along the entire length of affected digits

Incomplete Syndactyly

Webbing along only part of the length of the affected digits.

Complicated Syndactyly

Accessory Phalanges or abnormal bones involved in fusion.

Nonoperative Management
  • Mild or incomplete syndactyly and syndactyly of toes are often managed non-operatively, especially when the function is unaffected.

Operative Management
  • Surgical Timing:
    • Performed around 12-18 months of age to reduce scar contractures.
    • Early surgery (around 6 months) is advised for border digits (thumb, little finger) to prevent deformity.
  • Surgical Technique:
    • Zigzag incisions (e.g., the Cronin technique) are used to separate digits and minimise scar contracture.
    • Avoid simultaneous separation of both sides of a digit to protect blood supply.
  • Complex Syndactyly: May require bone separation (synostosis) with techniques like closing wedge osteotomies/ amputation

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 9-year-old boy who is experiencing pain, limping, and has had worsening symptoms for the past 6 months? The child seems to be in good overall health, with normal height and weight. Upon examination, there is slight muscle loss on the right side, limited ability to move the hip outwards (especially when flexed), and internal rotation is restricted due to pain.
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Idiopathic osteonecrosis or idiopathic avascular necrosis of the capital femoral epiphysis of the femoral head.

Etiopathogenesis
  • Idiopathic or etiology that would disrupt the blood flow to femoral epiphysis.
  • Coagulopathy and steroid use.

Includes 4 phases

  • Necrosis: Disruption of the blood supply leads to infarction of the femoral capital epiphysis.
  • Fragmentation: The body reabsorbs the infarcted bone.
  • Reossification: Osteoblastic activity takes over, and the femoral epiphysis reestablishes.
  • Remodeling: The new femoral head may be enlarged or flattened. It reshapes during growth.

Risk factors
  • Familial ~ 10%
  • Factor V Leiden/Thrombophilias (increased clotting)
  • Hypofibrinolysis (decreased ability to dissolve clots)
  • Low socioeconomic status
  • Birth weight less than 2.5 kg in boys

Clinical features
  • Limp of acute or insidious onset, usually painless.
  • If pain is present, it is localized to the hip or knee.
  • Decreased internal rotation and abduction of hip.
  • Atrophy of thighs and buttocks.
  • Limb length discrepancy.
  • Antalgic gait in acute cases and Trendelenburg gait in chronic cases.

Diagnosis
  • Standard anteroposterior pelvis and frog-leg lateral (Lauenstein) X-ray views.
  • Bone scan or MRI

 

Early findings:

  • Widening of joint space (epiphyseal cartilage hypertrophy)
  • Changes in the epiphysis.
  • Crescent sign: Subchondral radiolucent zone of the anterolateral epiphysis

Late signs:

  • Flattening of the femoral head.
  • Bone scan shows decreased perfusion to the femoral head.

Treatment

Non operative:

  • Indicated for children with bone age less than 6 or lateral pillar A involvement.
  • Activity restriction and protective weight-bearing are recommended until ossification is complete.

Operative treatment:

  • Femoral or Pelvic Osteotomy indicated in children older than 8 years.
  • Valgus or Shelf Osteotomies indicated in children with hinge abduction
  • Hip replacement procedures: if Arthritis has developed

questions.text: A 74-year-old man, who was previously a weightlifter, presented with lower back pain that was radiating to his legs. On examination , a palpable step was felt in the lumbosacral region of the spine. The x-ray of the spine is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Spondylolisthesis

               

  • It refers to the forward displacement of a vertebra over the one beneath it
  • Commonly occurring at the L5-S1 and L4-L5 levels.
  • Spondylolysis refers to a defect in the pars without the vertebra slipping forward.

Classification

Dysplastic

  • Least common type
  • Caused by congenital anomalies in the upper sacrum or L5 arch, facilitating the slip.

Isthmic

  • The most common type
  • Involving a lesion in the pars interarticularis, which can be further divided into three subtypes:
  • Lytic: A fatigue fracture of the pars interarticularis.
  • Intact but elongated: The pars interarticularis remains intact but is elongated.
  • Acute fracture: A recent fracture of the pars interarticularis. The defect causes the anterior half of the vertebra to slip forward while the posterior half remains with the lower vertebra.

Degenerative

  • Results from long-term intersegmental instability, where the pars remains intact, but degenerative changes in the facet joints permit forward slipping.
  • Common in older adults, where instability in the posterior facet joints due to osteoarthritis can lead to displacement, occasionally backwards (retrolisthesis).
  • Severe displacement and neurological issues are rare.

Traumatic

This results from fractures in other parts of the bony structure rather than in the pars interarticularis.

Pathological

Caused by generalized or localized bone diseases that weaken the vertebral articulations.

Normal appearance

Spondylolysis (Option A)

Spondylolisthesis (Option B)
  • Resembles a Scottish dog
  • Collar Appearance: Indicates a defect in the isthmus (pars interarticularis)
  • Defect without vertebral displacement
  • Separated Head and Neck
  • Defect with vertebral displacement

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presented with complaints of a gradually progressive swelling around her wrist joint for 3 months. Given below is the image of the X-ray film. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Benign but locally aggressive tumor of bone.
  • It commonly arises from epiphysis.
  • MC Age: 20 and 45 years of age.
  • Females > males.

Sites affected
  • Distal femur > proximal tibia > distal radius > sacrum.

Malignancy
  • Malignant transformation in <1% of cases.
  • Lungs are the most common site for metastases.

Clinical features
  • Swelling, vague pain.
  • Pathological fracture.

Radiology
  • X-ray: Expansile eccentric lytic lesion on epiphysis

Histo- pathology
  • Multinucleated giant cells and a background network of spindle-shaped mononuclear stromal cells.

Management
  • Extended curettage with Bone grafting

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with supraspinatus tendinitis. What degree of movement of the shoulder would present with pain in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Pain in the shoulder and upper arm during the mid-range (60-120 degrees) of gleno-humeral abduction. (Option B)

Causes
  • Minor tears of the supraspinatus tendon
  • Supraspinatus tendinitis
  • Calcification of supraspinatus tendon
  • Subacromial bursitis
  • Fracture of the greater tuberosity

Pathogenesis
  • The space between the upper end of the humerus and the acromion gets compromised, leading to the rotator cuff tendon being pinched between the greater tuberosity and the acromion during mid-abduction.

Clinical Features
  • Pain during mid-range of gleno-humeral abduction
  • Tenderness at the supraspinatus tendon or subacromial space
  • Restriction of shoulder movements

Treatment
  • Ultrasound therapy to the tender point
  • Anti-inflammatory drugs
  • Injection of hydrocortisone into the subacromial space
  • Excision of the anterior part of the acromion

Mechanism of action

↓

↓

↓

  • They have a lower risk of ovarian hyperstimulation.
  • They offer complete suppression of endogenous gonadotropins.

GnRH agonist

↓

↓

↓

Drugs
  • Cetrorelix
  • Ganirelix
  • Degarelix
  • Abarelix
  • Elagolix
  • Leuprolide
  • Goserelin
  • Histrelin
  • Buserelin
  • Triptorelin

Uses

  • Endometriosis.
  • In Vitro Fertilization (Suppression of endogenous Gonadotropin before administration of exogenous hormones).
  • Delayed puberty
  • Precocious puberty
  • Anovulation
  • Endometriosis

 

Intermittent injection

Continuous injection

Mechanism of action

This is used when increased gonadotropin secretion is needed. As an agonist, its initial action stimulates the GnRH receptors, resulting in the release of gonadotropins.

This is preferred when decreased levels of gonadotropins or sex hormones are needed. Continuous stimulation results in a negative feedback mechanism on the receptors, leading to their downregulation.

  • DOC in Precocious puberty.

Adverse effects

Postmenopausal symptoms include hot flashes, Osteoporosis and Depression.

questions.text: What is the pattern of inheritance for hemophilia A?
questions.explanation:
Definition
  • Hemophilia A is a genetic bleeding disorder that affects the blood's ability to clot properly due to a deficiency of clotting factor VIII.

Inheritance
  • Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder, which means it primarily affects males.
  • Females can be carriers of the condition.

Symptoms
  • Excessive or prolonged bleeding after injuries or surgeries.
  • Frequent nosebleeds.
  • Easy bruising.
  • Bleeding into joints, leading to pain and swelling.

Diagnosis
  • Blood tests to measure the level of clotting factor VIII.
  • Genetic testing to identify the specific mutation.

Treatment
  • Replacement therapy: Regular infusion of clotting factor VIll concentrates.
  • Desmopressin DDAVP): Stimulates the release of stored clotting factor VIII.
  • Gene therapy: Emerging treatment option to introduce the missing clotting factor gene.

Complications
  • Joint damage: Repeated bleeding into the joints can cause permanent damage and limited mobility.
  • Intracranial bleeding: Severe cases may result in bleeding inside the skull, which can be life-threatening.

questions.text: Which of the medications listed below is considered safe for the treatment of pregnancy-induced hypertension?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Alpha methyldopa

Antihypertensives in Pregnancy
  • DOC: Labetaolol (Beta-blocker)
  • If chronic hypertension develops, Alpha methyldopa
  • Safe antihypertensives during pregnancy
  • Labetalol, Hydralazine, Methyldopa, and Calcium channel blockers like Nifedipine. (LHMC- Lady Hardinge Medical College)

Unsafe antihypertensive drugs during pregnancy:

  • ACE inhibitors (Option A) & ARBs (Option D): Can lead to renal agenesis in the fetus, causing oligohydramnios and leading to POTTER sequence (Pulmonary hypoplasia, Oligohydramnios, Twisted/wrinkled skin, Twisted Potter faces, Extremity defects, Renal agenesis).
  • Thiazides/Loop diuretics/Beta-blockers (Option B): Bear the risk of placental ischemia, which can be fatal to the fetus.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with complaints of slowly progressive difficulty hearing in the right ear. She also has pulsatile tinnitus. On examination, a reddish mass was seen behind the tympanic membrane, and an audible bruit was heard over the mastoid when auscultation with a stethoscope was performed. Her Rinne test was negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Type

Glomus Tympanicum

Glomus Jugulare

Location

Tumours arise from the promontory of the middle ear.

Tumours originate from the dome of the jugular bulb and can extend into the middle ear and surrounding structures.

Manifestations

Pulsatile tinnitus, hearing loss, and a reddish mass behind the tympanic membrane.

Pulsatile tinnitus, hearing loss, and may involve multiple cranial nerves (IX, X, XI)

Otoscopy findings
  • Reddish, pulsatile mass behind the tympanic membrane.
  • This may lead to conductive hearing loss and a feeling of fullness in the ear.
  • Reddish mass behind the tympanic membrane, often pulsatile.
  • It is associated with neurological symptoms due to cranial nerve involvement, including glossopharyngeal nerve involvement.

Investigations of Glomus Tumour

CT scan
  • CECT (contrast-enhanced computed tomography) is the investigation of choice to distinguish between glomus tympanicum and glomus jugulare tumours and to differentiate them from an aberrant carotid artery, a high jugular bulb, or a dehiscent jugular bulb.
  • Phelps sign: On the normal side, the carotico-jugular spine (a dense bone structure between the jugular and mastoid) is intact. On the affected side, erosion of the carotico-jugular spine is observed.

MRI scan

  • It demonstrates the extent of the tumour within the soft tissue.
  • Salt and pepper sign: Microhemorrhages within the tumour are visualized as white and gray dots on MRI, resulting in a "salt-and-pepper" appearance.

Angiography

It is essential when CT indicates involvement of the jugular bulb, carotid artery, or intradural extension. It also aids in identifying additional glomus tumors, locating feeding vessels, and guiding embolization.

Brain Perfusion and Flow Studies

  • These are essential if the tumor compresses the internal carotid artery.
  • They assess brain perfusion, contralateral carotid artery function, and may involve xenon blood flow and isotope studies to gauge stroke risk and the need for artery replacement.

Biopsy
  • Histopathological studies show the Zell Ballen pattern, where epithelioid chief cells and sustentacular supporting cells form clusters (Zell Ballen) encircled by extensive vascular sinusoids.
  • Preoperative biopsy of the tumour is not performed due to the risk of profuse bleeding from its highly vascular thin-walled blood sinusoids and potential injury to the high jugular bulb or aberrant internal carotid artery.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with a chronic dry cough with no fever or other associated symptoms. He had recently been started on an antihypertensive for hypertension. Which among the following is most likely responsible for causing these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Only bradykinin

Adverse Effect

Description

Hypotension

Decrease in blood pressure, especially upon initiation of therapy or with dosage increases.

Hyperkalemia

Increased serum potassium levels due to reduced aldosterone secretion.

Cough

Persistent dry cough, possibly due to bradykinin buildup in the lungs.

Angioedema

Due to increased bradykinin levels, swelling of deeper layers of skin, particularly around the eyes and lips, can be life-threatening.

Rashes/Urticaria

Skin reactions like rashes or hives occur in a small percentage of users.

Dysgeusia

Reversible taste changes are more common with captopril.

Rare Effects

Granulocytopenia (low white blood cells) and proteinuria (excess protein in urine) are more concerning in patients with kidney disease.

Acute Renal Failure

Possible in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis due to decreased kidney filtration.

Fetal Effects

ACE inhibitors are contraindicated during pregnancy due to potential harm to the fetus, including fetal renal damage due to inhibition of the fetal renin-angiotensin system.

questions.text: What is the recommended course of action for managing a 6-year-old boy who fell from a bed and now has swelling in his nose, along with breathing difficulties? During examination, it was observed that there are smooth, rounded swellings on both sides of the septum, visible through both nostrils. On palpation, the swellings were found to be soft and fluctuant.
questions.explanation:
Aetiology
  • Collection of blood under the perichondrium or periosteum of the nasal septum.
  • Commonly caused by:
    • Nasal trauma.
    • Septal surgery.
    • Spontaneous occurrence in bleeding disorders.

Clinical features
  • Bilateral nasal obstruction (most common symptom).
  • Frontal headache and pressure over the nasal bridge.
  • Smooth, rounded, soft, and fluctuant swelling in both nasal fossae (or sometimes unilateral).

Treatment
  • Small hematomas: Aspirated with a wide-bore sterile needle.
  • Larger hematomas: Incision and drainage via a septal incision parallel to the nasal floor, excising a small piece of mucosa for better drainage.
  • Nasal packing on both sides to prevent reaccumulation.
  • Systemic antibiotics to prevent septal abscess.

Complications
  • Fibrous tissue formation leads to permanent septal thickening if untreated.
  • Secondary infection may lead to septal abscess, cartilage necrosis, and nasal dorsum depression.

questions.text: A 55 year old shipbuilding worker presents with dyspnea. He has been working in this industry for the past 25 years. Which is the most specific malignancy that we can expect in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Mesothelioma
  • A rare cancer arising from mesothelial cells that most commonly affects the pleura.
  • It can also affect the peritoneum, pericardium and tunica vaginalis.

Aetiology

  • Asbestos: Mesothelioma is the most specific asbestos-associated cancer .
  • It is not associated with smoking.

Pathology

  • Advanced pleural mesothelioma can cause extensive pleural fibrosis and thickening, making the affected side rigid and immobile.
  • Later stages fix the mediastinum in place due to pleural thickening and fibrosis.
  • The mediastinal shift is not a characteristic feature of mesothelioma.
  • M/C cytogenetic abnormality in mesothelioma: Homozygous deletion of chromosome 9p, leading to loss of tumour suppressor gene- CDKN2A.

Clinical features

  • Progressive dyspnea, chest pain, weight loss, chronic cough, hemoptysis.
  • Decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion (due to pleural effusion or thickening).

Diagnosis

  • CT scan: Pleural thickening, effusion, or frozen hemithorax (not causing a mediastinal shift in the presence of effusion)
  • Confirmed by biopsy:
    • Epithelioid mesothelioma shows tubules, nests, or papillary structures with uniform round to oval nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm.
    • Sarcomatoid mesothelioma consists of spindle-shaped cells resembling fibrosarcoma.
    • Biphasic mesothelioma displays a mixture of both patterns.
  • Specific markers for mesothelioma:
    • Calretinin.
    • Epithelial membrane antigen.
    • Cytokeratin.
    • Mesothelin.

Mesothelioma- Gross

Mesothelioma- H & E stain

Mesothelioma- Calretinin stain

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of alteplase, a tissue plasminogen activator (tPA)?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Promotes fibrinolysis

Fibrinolytic Drugs (Thrombolytics)

  

Mechanism

Activate plasminogen to plasmin via tissue plasminogen activator (t-PA)→ digests fibrin →lyse thrombi to recanalize occluded blood vessels, primarily coronary arteries.

  
 

Examples

  • Streptokinase (not in use)
  • Urokinase (not in use)
  • Alteplase
  • Reteplase
  • Tenecteplase

 

Uses
  • Acute Myocardial Infarction (STEMI)
    • The chief indication is for STEMI.
    • Not indicated for unstable angina (UA) and low-risk NSTEMI.
    • Alternative to emergency PCI.
  • Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)
  • Pulmonary Embolism (PE)
    • Indicated for large, life-threatening PE
  • Peripheral Arterial Occlusion
    • Indicated when surgical thrombectomy is not possible.
  • Stroke (Ischemic Stroke)
    • Alteplase is approved
    • Contraindicated after 4.5 hours of symptom onset due to increased intracranial hemorrhage risk.

 

Contraindications

  • History of intracranial hemorrhage.
  • History of ischemic stroke in the past 3 months.
  • History of head injury in the past 3 months.
  • Intracranial tumor/vascular abnormality/aneurysms.
  • Active bleeding/bleeding disorders.
  • Patients on anticoagulants.
  • Peptic ulcer, esophageal varices.
  • Recent wound, fracture, or tooth extraction.
  • Major surgery within the past 3 weeks.
  • Uncontrolled hypertension.
  • Pregnancy.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for an older diabetic woman,who received steroids and remdesivir for COVID, and is now experiencing a malodorous black discharge from her nose? On examination a necrotic black mass, filling the nasal cavity and causing erosion of the septum and hard palate is found.
questions.explanation:
Mucormycosis

Description

A severe fungal infection primarily affects the nose and sinuses but can quickly spread to the orbit, cribriform plate, meninges, and brain. The fungus invades arteries, causing endothelial damage, thrombosis, and rapid tissue destruction.

Characteristic Findings

Black necrotic material in the nasal cavity, eroding the nasal septum, hard palate, and turbinates. Black turbinate sign is seen on contrast enhanced MRI.

Risk Factors
  • Uncontrolled diabetes, especially with ketoacidosis
  • Prolonged steroid use (common in COVID-19 treatment)
  • Conditions causing immunosuppression: Neutropenia, HIV/AIDS, chemotherapy, organ transplants, and kidney issues.

Diagnosis
  • Endoscopy: Shows pale mucosa early, progressing to black crusts and sloughing.
  • Biopsy: Multiple sites should be sampled for fungal identification; potassium hydroxide preparation is the gold standard for confirming invasive features.

Imaging
  • CT: Detects bony destruction and initial assessment of sinus involvement.
  • CECT: CECT provides better delineation of soft tissue structures, allowing for clearer identification of mucosal thickening, sinus opacification, and bony destruction.
  • MRI: Evaluates soft tissue invasion, assesses the extent of extra-sinus disease, and identifies complications, especially in the orbit and brain.

Treatment

Antifungal Therapy:

  • Amphotericin B: 0.6 to 1 mg/kg/day IV or liposomal Amphotericin B: 5 mg/kg/day.
  • Posaconazole: 300 mg twice daily orally on the first day, then 300 mg once daily.

Surgical Intervention:

  • Endoscopic debridement of necrotic tissues.
  • Severe cases: Total/Partial maxillectomy or orbital exenteration may be required.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented with a history of yellowing of the skin and eyes for 11 weeks, but he does not have any other symptoms. He had a viral infection 10 days ago and experienced a similar episode of yellowing 2 years ago for 2 weeks. Upon further questioning, he mentioned having long hours of basketball practice 2 years ago, which left him physically exhausted. His current blood tests show a serum bilirubin level of 2.4 mg/dL, with unconjugated bilirubin at 2.1 mg/dL and conjugated bilirubin at 0.3 mg/dL. His liver enzyme levels (AST and ALT) are normal. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Gilbert Syndrome

About
  • Gilber Gilbert Syndrome (GS) is a common, benign condition with mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and normal liver function tests, affecting up to 8% of people, more common in males.

Pathophysiology
  • Caused by reduced UGT1A1 enzyme activity (10–35% of normal), often due to a TA insertion variant in the UGT1A1 promoter (A[TA]7TAA).
  • Inheritance is typically autosomal recessive with the promoter variant; some cases show dominant inheritance with other mutations.

Clinical Features

 
  • Serum bilirubin <51 μmol/L (<3 mg/dL), fluctuating with stress, fasting, alcohol, or illness; jaundice may occur during elevations.
  • Most patients are asymptomatic, though jaundice can occur during episodes of elevated bilirubin levels.
  • Often diagnosed incidentally in adolescence or adulthood.

Investigations
  • Serum bilirubin levels are intermittently high, with Normal liver function tests and hepatic histology.
  • UGT1A1 gene testing may reveal the A[TA]7TAA promoter variant.

Management
  • Lifestyle adjustments, such as avoiding alcohol and maintaining regular calorie intake, may help manage bilirubin levels.
  • Phenobarbital can normalize bilirubin levels if required.
  • Caution with drugs metabolized by UGT1A1 (e.g., irinotecan, HIV protease inhibitors) due to risk of toxicity.

questions.text: Gastric lavage, commonly known as stomach pumping or gastric irrigation, is a procedure performed to remove the contents of the stomach. It has been widely used since the early 19th century as a standard method to eliminate toxins from the stomach. This procedure is typically employed for individuals who have consumed poison or overdosed on substances like ethanol. Additionally, it may be performed prior to surgery to empty the digestive tract. In which of the following situations is gastric lavage not recommended?
questions.explanation:
Step

Details

Patient Positioning

Trendelenburg: Head down to prevent aspiration

Left lateral decubitus: Reduces chance of poison entering the duodenum

Tube Placement Confirmation

Inject air and listen for gastric bubbling sounds

Watch for coughing or bubbles (indicates misplacement in trachea)

Fluid Administration

Fluid is administered and aspirated using a syringe attached to the tube

Fluid Selection

Tap water for most cases

Normal saline for infants

Specific solutions (e.g., potassium permanganate) may be used for certain poisons

Residual Fluid

Leave a small amount of fluid to neutralize remaining poison

Complication

Details

Aspiration

Occurs in ~10% of cases. Risk of lung injury

Esophageal/Gastric Perforation

Can be life-threatening

Tube Misplacement

Misplaced into trachea, causing complications

Bleeding

Can occur with improper technique or pathology

Alternative

Description

Emetics

Induce vomiting in conscious patients

Dilution

Large water intake to dilute corrosive substances

Endoscopic/Surgical Removal

Used for toxic foreign bodies or drug packets

questions.explanation:
Fat Embolism Causes

Blunt trauma: Accounts for 90% of cases, especially involving extremity fractures.

 

Associated conditions:

  • Acute pancreatitis
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Burns
  • Joint reconstruction surgeries
  • Liposuction
  • Cardiopulmonary bypass
  • Decompression sickness

  • Sickle cell crisis

questions.text: Which of the following imaging tests should be performed to confirm a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism in a patient?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Evaluation

 

PE symptoms are nonspecific, often leading to excessive use of CT pulmonary angiograms. Age-adjusted d-dimer testing is recommended for patients over 50 years with low-to-moderate PE probability.

D-Dimer

A sensitive but nonspecific test for PE. Elevated levels indicate possible PE but can also occur with conditions like MI, pneumonia, or sepsis. Normal d-dimer helps rule out PE.

Electrocardiogram (ECG)

Common findings include sinus tachycardia(most common) and the S1Q3T3 sign (most specific) (S wave in lead I, Q wave in lead III, inverted T wave in lead III). T-wave inversion in V1 to V4 suggests RV strain or ischemia.

Venous Ultrasonography

Uses loss of vein compressibility as a key indicator for diagnosing DVT, which is associated with PE. Doppler imaging can assess blood flow dynamics.

Chest X-ray

Often normal but may show specific signs like Westermark’s sign (focal oligemia), Hampton’s hump (wedge-shaped pleural density), or Palla’s sign (enlarged pulmonary artery).

Chest radiograph demonstrating focal oligemia (Westermark’s sign) in the right lung (area between white arrowheads) and a prominent right descending pulmonary artery (Palla’s sign) (black arrow).

The chest radiograph demonstrates a wedge-shaped opacity (arrow) in the right middle lobe consistent with Hampton hump.

Chest CT with Contrast

 

The primary imaging test. It offers high-resolution visualisation of pulmonary vasculature. RV enlargement on CT indicates a higher risk of mortality.

Lung Scanning

A second-line test, mostly for patients who can’t tolerate contrast. High-probability perfusion scans (two or more segmental perfusion defects) strongly suggest PE.

Magnetic Resonance (MR) Imaging

MR venography with gadolinium can diagnose DVT when ultrasound is inconclusive, though MR pulmonary angiography (Option D) is less reliable for smaller PEs.

Echocardiography

It is not reliable (Option A) for directly diagnosing PE but useful for detecting mimicking conditions. McConnell’s sign (RV-free wall hypokinesis) is an indirect sign of PE.

CT Pulmonary Angiography

Identifies intraluminal filling defects or abrupt vessel occlusion.

questions.text: A patient has presented with features of cardiac tamponade. Which of the following is correct regarding this condition?

options.label: D
options.text: Jugular veins column is visibly distended without pulsations

questions.correct_answer: D. Jugular veins column is visibly distended without pulsations
questions.explanation:
Cardiac Tamponade

Definition

A condition where the cardiac chambers are compressed by a tense pericardial effusion, limiting cardiac inflow. Fluid accumulation of as little as 200 ml to upwards of 2L may lead to cardiac tamponade development.

Beck's triad
  • Jugular Venous Distension: Due to increased central venous pressure. Prominent x descent and an absent y descent.
  • Hypotension: Resulting from impaired cardiac output.
  • Muffled Heart Sounds: Caused by fluid accumulation in the pericardial space, dampening heart sounds.

Other Clinical features

Pulsus Paradoxus: A drop in systolic BP during inspiration, greater than 10 mm Hg. It is present in most of the conditions but not always(Option A) and can vary depending on the severity of tamponade and other factors.

Causes of Pulsus paradoxus:

  • Lung Conditions: Acute asthma, COPD, tension pneumothorax, pleural effusion, pulmonary embolism.
  • Heart Conditions: Cardiac tamponade, constrictive pericarditis.

questions.text: The most reliable criteria among Gustafson's criteria for age estimation is?
What is the first postmortem change that occurs in a dead body?

options.label: C
options.text: Greenish discoloration of right iliac fossa

questions.correct_answer: C. Greenish discoloration of right iliac fossa
questions.explanation:
Autolysis

Putrefaction

Autolysis is the self-digestion of tissues caused by the body’s own enzymes after death.

 

Characteristics of Autolysis:

  • Initiation: Begins immediately after death when metabolic processes cease.
  • Mechanism: Enzymatic action leads to cell lysis, altering tissue appearance and texture.

Examples of Autolytic Changes:

  • Clouding of the Cornea: The first observable external change, losing transparency due to cellular breakdown.
  • Changes in Brain Glandular Tissue: The first internal change, where neuronal and glial cells undergo lysis.

Note:

Aseptic Autolysis: Occurs in intrauterine fetal demise, leading to mummification without bacterial involvement.

Putrefaction is driven by bacterial activity, resulting in tissue breakdown and gas production.

Characteristics of Putrefaction:

  • Bacterial Involvement: Primarily caused by Clostridium perfringens.
  • Lytic Enzyme: The main enzyme involved is lecithinase, which breaks down cell membranes.

Stages of Putrefaction:

  1. Color Change:
    • The first internal change is reddish-brown discoloration of the aortic intima.
    • The first external change is green discoloration in the right iliac fossa due to the breakdown of hemoglobin.
  2. Mechanism of Color Change:
    • Hydrogen Sulfide Production: Bacteria produce hydrogen sulfide, which forms a green compound with hemoglobin.
    • The cecum is the primary site of discoloration due to high bacterial activity.
  3. Gas Formation:
    • Gas production leads to bloating, with gases like carbon dioxide, methane, and hydrogen sulfide.
  4. Liquefaction of Tissue:
    • Tissues become liquefied, losing structural integrity, contributing to the characteristic odor of decomposition.
  5. Timing of Discoloration:
    • Discoloration begins within 12-18 hours in summer and 1-2 days in winter, influenced by temperature and bacterial activity.

questions.text: What is the association of Rhino-cerebral Mucor mycosis?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Overview

Severe fungal infection affecting nasal passages, sinuses, and brain.

Causative Agent

Primarily caused by Rhizopus oryzae, associated with uncontrolled DM and diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA).

Pathophysiology

Begins in nasal turbinates; progresses rapidly due to angioinvasive nature, causing tissue necrosis and vascular thrombosis.

Clinical Manifestations

Fever, facial pain, swelling, nasal discharge, necrotic eschar.

Diagnosis

Imaging studies and histopathological examination.

Treatment

Immediate antifungal therapy (e.g., amphotericin B) and aggressive surgical debridement.

questions.text: Which of the following is not done in W.P.W?
questions.explanation:
WPW Syndrome

Most common type of ventricular preexcitation syndrome, characterized by preexcited QRS during sinus rhythm and episodes of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT).

Mechanism

Abnormal conduction pathway from atria to the ventricle (Bundle of Kent) bypasses the rate-slowing AV node, causing partial early ventricular depolarisation.

ECG Findings

Delta wave with widened QRS complex and shortened PR interval.

Clinical Consequence

May lead to a reentry circuit, causing paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT).

questions.text: A couple brought their son to doctor. They were worried because their son likes to eat foods from multinational companies. What will we call this shift from consumption of traditional natural food to western fast foods?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Acculturation

Term

Definition/Explanation

Social structure

Patterns of inter-relationships between persons in a society

Socialism

Economic doctrine that favours the use of property and resources of the country for public welfare; system of production and distribution based on social ownership

Socialization

Process by which an individual gradually acquires culture and becomes a member of a social group

Medical sociology

Includes studies of medical profession, relationship of medicine to public, social factors in disease prevalence, incidence, and interpretation

Society

A group of individuals who have organized themselves and follow a way of life, featuring a system of relationships between individuals

Community

A social group determined by geographical boundaries and/or common values or interests

Sociology

Study of individuals as well as groups in society, focusing on relationships and behavior

Culture

Learned behavior socially acquired

Acculturation

Cultural contact or mixing of two cultures through trade, industrialization, religion propagation, education, and conquest

Custom
  • Established patterns of behavior objectively verified within a particular social setting
  • Folkways: Right ways of doing things in less vital areas of human conduct
  • Mores: More stringent customs within society

 

Standard of Living

Refers to usual scale of expenditure, goods consumed, and services enjoyed, including income, occupation, housing, sanitation, nutrition, health, education, recreational services

Social Pathology

(Option B)

Study of social problems that undermine the social, psychological, or economic health of populations; describes the relationship between disease and social conditions

questions.text: A woman who underwent dilatation and curettage for molar pregnancy six months ago presents with persistent abdominal pain and distention symptoms. On further evaluation, the beta-hCG levels were persistently elevated, and cannonball foci were found on the chest X-ray. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Gestational Trophoblastic Disease

Definition and Classification
  • Hydatidiform Moles (HM):
    • Complete Mole: No fetal parts, abnormal placental development
    • Partial Mole: Some fetal parts present, abnormal placental tissue
  • Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia (GTN):
    • Invasive Mole: Deep penetration into uterine wall
    • Choriocarcinoma: Aggressive malignant form
    • Epithelioid Trophoblastic Tumor (ETT): Rare variant
    • Placental Site Trophoblastic Tumor (PSTT): Originating from implantation site

Risk Factors
  • Risk Factors:
    • Maternal age >35 or <21 years
    • Previous molar pregnancy (1% recurrence risk)
    • Asian ethnicity
    • History of spontaneous abortion
    • Dietary deficiencies (vitamin A, animal fats)
    • Blood type A

Pathogenesis and Genetics
  • Complete Mole:
    • 46,XX (90%) - all paternal chromosomes
    • 46,XY (10%) - all paternal chromosomes
    • Empty egg fertilized by sperm that duplicates
    • Maternal mitochondrial DNA present
  • Partial Mole:
    • Triploid: 69,XXX, 69,XXY, or 69,XYY
    • Fertilization by two sperm
    • Contains both maternal and paternal DNA
  • Molecular Features:
    • p53 and MDM2 overexpression
    • HLA-G expression in choriocarcinoma
    • Altered NECC1 and growth factor expression

Clinical Presentation
  • First Trimester:
    • Vaginal bleeding (84% of cases)
    • Dark brown/prune juice-like discharge
    • Passage of grape-like vesicles
    • Hyperemesis gravidarum
  • Later Presentation:
    • Hyperthyroidism symptoms
    • Early pre-eclampsia (<20 weeks)
    • Respiratory distress
    • Theca lutein cysts
  • Physical Findings:
    • Uterine size-date discrepancy
    • Absent fetal heart tones (complete mole)
    • Adnexal masses

Diagnostic Evaluation
  • Imaging Studies:
    • Ultrasound: "Snowstorm" or "grape-like" pattern
    • Chest X-ray for metastasis (Cannonball foci in lungs)
    • ​​​​​​​
    • CT/PET for staging
    • MRI for atypical presentations
  • Laboratory Tests:
    • Quantitative β-hCG levels
    • Complete blood count
    • Coagulation studies
    • Liver and renal function
    • Thyroid function tests
  • Histopathological Features:
    • Complete Mole: Diffuse villous edema, trophoblastic hyperplasia
    • Partial Mole: Mixed normal and hydropic villi
    • Choriocarcinoma: Biphasic pattern with hemorrhage

Type of GTD

Description

Fetal Development

Placental Appearance

Malignancy Potential

Hydatidiform Mole

A noncancerous growth in the uterus that forms from the abnormal fertilization of an egg by sperm.

Variable

Abnormal

Rarely malignant

Partial Hydatidiform Mole

A type of hydatidiform mole characterized by some fetal development and an abnormal placenta.

Some

Abnormal

Rarely malignant

Complete Hydatidiform Mole

A type of hydatidiform mole characterized by the absence of a fetus and a complete abnormal placenta.

None

Abnormal

Rarely malignant

Invasive Mole

A rare condition where a hydatidiform mole penetrates deeply into the uterine wall.

None

Abnormal

Can be locally invasive

Choriocarcinoma

A malignant form of GTD that can develop from a hydatidiform mole, a normal pregnancy, or a miscarriage.

None

Abnormal

Highly malignant

Placental-site Trophoblastic Tumor

A rare form of GTD that develops in the placental implantation site after a normal pregnancy.

None

Abnormal

Locally invasive

questions.text: Modified duke criteria are used for diagnosis of?
questions.explanation:
I. Definite Endocarditis:

A. Pathologic Criteria

1. Microorganisms identified in the context of clinical signs of active endocarditis in a vegetation from cardiac tissue; from explanted prosthetic valve or sewing ring; from ascending aortic graft (with concomitant evidence of valve involvement); from an endovascular intra cardiac implantable electronic device (CIED) or from an arterial embolus OR

2. Active endocarditis in the same above mentioned locations.

  • Microorganisms identified in appropriate sample by PCR, amplicon or metagenomic sequencing, or in situ hybridization

B. Clinical Criteria (mentioned below)

1. 2 Major Criteria OR

2. 1 Major and 3 Minor Criteria OR

3. 5 Minor Criteria

II. Possible Endocarditis:

A. 1 Major Criterion and 1 Minor Criterion OR

B. 3 Minor Criteria

III. Rejected Endocarditis:

A. Firm alternate diagnosis explaining signs/symptoms OR

B. Lack of recurrence despite antibiotic therapy for only < 4 days OR

C. No pathologic/macroscopic evidence of IE at surgery or autopsy with antibiotic therapy for less than 4 days OR

D. Does not meet criteria of possible IE

Clinical Criteria

I. Major Criteria

A. Microbiologic Major Criteria

(i) Positive blood cultures

Microorganisms that commonly cause IE isolated from 2 or more separate blood culture sets

OR

Microorganisms that occasionally or rarely cause IE isolated from 3 or more separate blood culture sets

(ii) Positive laboratory tests

Positive polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or other nucleic acid-based technique for Coxiella burnetii, Bartonella species, or Tropheryma whipplei from blood

OR

Coxiella burnetii antiphase I immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibody titer > 1:800 or isolated from a single blood culture

OR

Indirect immunofluorescence assays (IFA) for IgM and IgG antibodies to Bartonella henselae or Bartonella quintana with IgG titer ≥ 1:800

B. Imaging Major Criteria

(i) Echocardiography and cardiac computed tomography (CT) imaging

Echocardiography and cardiac CT showing vegetation, valve/leaflet perforation, valve/leaflet aneurysm, abscess, pseudoaneurysm, or intracardiac fistula

OR

Significant new valvular regurgitation on echocardiography as compared with previous imaging.

Worsening or changing of preexisting regurgitation is not sufficient

OR

New partial dehiscence of prosthetic valve as compared with previous imaging.

(ii) 18F-FDG PET/CT imaging

Abnormal metabolic activity involving a native or prosthetic valve, ascending aortic graft (with concomitant evidence of valve involvement), intracardiac device leads, or other prosthetic material

C. Surgical Major Criteria

Evidence of IE documented by direct inspection during heart surgery neither Major Imaging Criteria nor subsequent histologic or microbiologic confirmation

II. MINOR CRITERIA

A. Predisposition
  • Previous history of IE
  • Prosthetic valve
  • Previous valve repair
  • Congenital heart disease
  • More than mild regurgitation or stenosis of any etiology
  • Endovascular intracardiac implantable electronic device (CIED)
  • Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy
  • Intravenous drug use

B. Fever

Temperature greater than 38.0°C

C. Vascular Phenomena

Clinical or radiological evidence of arterial emboli, septic pulmonary infarcts, cerebral or splenic abscess, mycotic aneurysm, intracranial hemorrhage, conjunctival hemorrhages, Janeway lesions, purulent pericardium

D. Immunologic Phenomena

Positive rheumatoid factor, Osler nodes, Roth spots, or immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis

E. Microbiologic Evidence (Falling Short of Major Criterion)

Positive blood cultures for a microorganism consistent with IE but not meeting the requirements for Major Criterion

OR

Positive culture, PCR, or other nucleic acid-based test (amplicon or shotgun sequencing, in situ hybridization) for organisms consistent with IE from a sterile body site other than cardiac tissue, cardiac prosthesis, or arterial embolus

F. Imaging Criteria

Abnormal 18F-FDG PET/CT within 3 months of implantation of prosthetic valve

G. Physical Examination Criteria

New valvular regurgitation identified on auscultation if echocardiography is not available.

Description

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)

DIC is a condition characterized by widespread activation of blood clotting mechanisms, leading to the formation of small clots throughout the body

Preeclampsia is a hypertensive disorder that can lead to organ damage, including liver dysfunction, which may trigger consumptive coagulopathy

HELLP syndrome

HELLP syndrome is a severe form of preeclampsia characterized by Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, and Low Platelet count

Acute fatty liver of pregnancy

This rare condition affects liver function and may result in a consumptive coagulopathy due to liver dysfunction

Septic abortion

Septic abortion refers to an infection of the products of conception, which can cause inflammation and abnormal clotting

Placenta percreta/increta/accreta

These conditions involve abnormal adherence of the placenta to the uterine wall, which can lead to significant bleeding and coagulation abnormalities

questions.explanation:
Different Side Effects Of Oxytocin And Their Causes

Side Effects

Causes

Uterine Hyperstimulation
  • High dosage or rapid increase in Oxytocin infusion rate
  • Prolonged administration of Oxytocin

Fetal Distress

Uterine hyperstimulation leading to decreased blood flow and oxygen supply to the fetus

Water Intoxication

Prolonged high-dose administration of Oxytocin

Nausea and Vomiting

Direct stimulation of the vomiting center in the brain by Oxytocin

Headache

Vasodilation and changes in cerebral blood flow caused by Oxytocin

Hypotension

Oxytocin-induced vasodilation and decreased systemic vascular resistance

Postpartum Hemorrhage

Rarely, high doses of Oxytocin may contribute to uterine atony or excessive uterine contractions

Allergic Reactions

Hypersensitivity or allergic response to Oxytocin or other components of the medication

Cardiac Arrhythmias

Direct effects of Oxytocin on cardiac electrical activity

Maternal Fluid Overload

Oxytocin-induced antidiuretic effect leading to fluid retention

Uterine Rupture (Rare)

Excessive uterine contractions or hyperstimulation of the uterus

Use

Recommended Dose

Adverse Effects

Induction of Labor

Initial: 0.5-1 milliunits/min IV infusion, gradually increasing by 1-2 milliunits/min every 15-60 min until desired contractions occur
  • Uterine hyperstimulation
  • Fetal distress
  • Water intoxication (rare, with prolonged high-dose administration)

Augmentation of Labor

Initial: 0.5-1 milliunits/min IV infusion, gradually increasing by 1-2 milliunits/min every 15-60 min as needed
  • Uterine hyperstimulation
  • Fetal distress

Prevention of Postpartum Hemorrhage

IV infusion: 10-40 units in 1000 mL of compatible IV solution, usually at a rate of 20-40 milliunits/min
  • Uterine hyperstimulation
  • Postpartum hemorrhage (rare, when given in excessive doses)

Management of Postpartum Hemorrhage

IV infusion: 10 units in 1000 mL of compatible IV solution, usually at a rate of 20-40 milliunits/min
  • Uterine hyperstimulation
  • Postpartum hemorrhage (rare, when given in excessive doses)

Uterine Atony

  • Uterine hyperstimulation
  • Postpartum hemorrhage (rare, when given in excessive doses)

Facilitation of Placental Delivery

IV infusion: 10 units in 1000 mL of compatible IV solution, usually at a rate of 20-40 milliunits/min
  • Uterine hyperstimulation
  • Postpartum hemorrhage (rare, when given in excessive doses)

Stimulation of Breast Milk Ejection

Intranasal spray: Single spray (40 IU) into one nostril approximately 5-10 min before breastfeeding or pumping

questions.text: A person was brought to the emergency department with facial swelling, itching, and hypotension following a bee sting. The mentioned clinical features are due to the increase in which of the following immunoglobulins?
questions.explanation:
Early phase reaction

Late phase reaction

Onset

Immediate (within minutes of allergen exposure).

Delayed (several hours after exposure) and can last for days.

Cells involved

Mast cells, basophils.

Eosinophils, T lymphocytes.

Cellular events

Activation of mast cells and basophils.

Recruitment and activation of leukocytes, especially eosinophils.

Mediators

Histamine, leukotrienes (LTB4, LTC4, LTD4), prostaglandins (PGD2) and Platelet-activating factor (PAF).

Cytokines (e.g., IL-4, IL-5, TNF), chemokines (e.g., eotaxin).

Initiating event

Exposure to allergen triggers cross-linking of IgE on mast cells/basophils.

Recurrent inflammation, sustained by recruited leukocytes.

Effect on tissues

Vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, smooth muscle contraction.

Sustained inflammation and tissue damage due to leukocyte infiltration.

Clinical manifestations

Allergic rhinitis (hay fever), urticaria (hives), Angioedema bronchoconstriction.

Allergic asthma exacerbation, persistent inflammation, and tissue damage.

Therapeutic Approach

Antihistamines for symptomatic relief.

Adrenaline in anaphylactic shock.

Broad-spectrum anti-inflammatory drugs (e.g., steroids) to suppress inflammation and prevent tissue damage.

questions.explanation:
Mechanisms of Type II hypersensitivity

Description

Examples

Opsonisation and Phagocytosis

IgG antibodies coat cells, helping phagocytes recognise circulating antigen-opsonin complexes through Fc receptors or complement activation, leading to phagocytosis.
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Immune thrombocytopenic purpura
  • Rh hemolytic disease of the newborn.

Complement activation

and inflammation
  • Antibody deposition in extracellular tissues triggers inflammation rather than phagocytosis or cell lysis.
  • The deposited antibodies activate the complement system, attracting neutrophils and monocytes via their Fc receptors.
  • Activated leukocytes release enzymes, causing tissue damage.
  • Goodpasture syndrome.
  • Acute rheumatic fever.

Antibody-dependent

cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC)
 

Natural killer cells bind to antibody-antigen complexes, inducing apoptotic cell death.
  • Pernicious anemia
  • Insulin resistant diabetes

Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction (non-cytotoxic)

Antibodies physically impair or dysregulate cellular function by binding to cell surface receptors. This includes both activation (e.g., thyroid hormone receptor in Graves disease) and inhibition (e.g., acetylcholine receptor in Myasthenia gravis).
  • Graves disease
  • Myasthenia gravis

Mnemonic: My Blood Group Is Rh Positive

My

Myasthenia Gravis

Blood

Blood transfusion reaction

Group

Good pasture syndrome,

Graves disease

Is

Immune hemolytic anaemia,

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura

R

Rh incompatibility,

Rheumatic fever

H

Hyperacute transplant rejection

Positive

Pemphigus (Bullous),

Pernicious Anemia

Type II hypersensitivity (Antibody-mediated)

Opsonisation and complement activation→Phagocytosis

Transfusion reaction, erythroblastosis fetalis, AIHA, ITP.

Complement, Fc receptor-mediated →Inflammation.

Goodpasture syndrome, Acute Rheumatic fever, vascular rejections, vasculitis.

Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunctions.

Myasthenia gravis, Pemphigus Vulgaris, Graves disease, Pernicious Anemia, Insulin-resistant diabetes, Hemolytic disease of the newborn.

questions.text: What is the primary risk factor for the disease in a patient who exhibits symptoms of a black, malodorous nasal discharge, along with the presence of a black, necrotic mass that fills the nasal cavity and causes erosion of the septum and hard palate during examination?
questions.explanation:
Mucormycosis

It is an invasive disease caused by zygomycetes (phycomycetes) - Rhizopus, Mucor and Absidia. Rhizopus Arrhizus is the most common pathogen

Rhizopus

 

 

Absidia Mucor (Lactophenol cotton blue stained)

Pathogenesis

Begins in the respiratory tract or nasal cavity, where spores germinate and form mycelia → invade adjacent tissues, leading to local destruction.

Fungi invade blood vessels, causing thrombosis and infarction in affected areas, which contributes to its high mortality rate (Angio-invasiveness)

Common Sites

Rhinocerebral Form: Involves the nose, nasal sinuses, and orbit; frequently seen in diabetic patients.

Pulmonary Infections: When the lungs are the primary site, the fungi can invade lung arteries, leading to serious complications.

Others: Cutaneous mucormycosis, GI mucormycosis, Disseminated mucormycosis

Clinical Features

Rhinocerebral Zygomycosis:

Facial swelling, nasal discharge (often black), fever, and mucosal necrosis.

Rapid progression can lead to severe complications, including visual loss and neurological symptoms.

Pulmonary Zygomycosis:

Symptoms may include cough, fever, and hemoptysis

Diagnosis

Histological Examination:

Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying broad, non-septate (or sparsely septate) hyphae.

Culture:

After incubation for 3-4 days on Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, the colonies are grey-white with a thick cottony, fluffy surface.

Under the microscope, nonseptate, broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium (a sac containing spores are seen.)

Sabouraud's dextrose agar (SDA) medium showing Rhizopus growth

Microscopy of LPCB stained preparation demonstrating morphology of Rhizopus spp. (non-septate hyphae, sporangiophore, sporangium and spores)

Treatment:

Intravenous amphotericin B combined, where appropriate, with surgical drainage is the recommended treatment.

Medical control of diabetes is required.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child was brought to your clinic with an erythematous rash on the cheek which later spread downwards to involve his trunk and limbs. He has also had a low-grade fever, headache, and mild upper respiratory tract infection for the past few days. The suspected organism contains single-stranded DNA. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Parvovirus

Morphology

  • Simplest animal viruses infecting humans, responsible for erythema infectiosum (fifth disease).
  • Smallest viruses (18–26 nm in size).
  • Non-enveloped with icosahedral symmetry.
  • Only DNA viruses with single-stranded DNA.
  • Dependent on host cell enzymes for replication.

Pathogenesis
  • Exclusively infects humans.
  • Transmission:
  • Primarily through the respiratory route.
  • Blood transfusion.
  • Transplacental transmission.
  • Target Cells: Tropism for erythroid progenitor cells in adult bone marrow and fetal liver.
  • Receptor Binding: Binds to blood group P antigen on RBC surface.
  • Effects: Leads to RBC destruction and inhibition of erythropoiesis, potentially causing anemia.

Clinical Manifestations of Parvovirus infections:
  • Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease) (Option A )
    • Children: "Slapped cheek" facial rash.
    • Adult women: Symmetrical polyarthropathy, often in hand and knee joints.
  • Transient Aplastic Crisis:
    • Severe acute anemia in patients with pre-existing hemolytic anemia.
  • Pure Red Cell Aplasia:
    • Chronic anemia in immunocompromised individuals due to persistent B19 infection.
  • Non-Immune Hydrops Fetalis:
    • Fatal fetal anemia and death; occurs via transplacental transmission (30% of cases)
    • Highest risk in the second trimester.
  • Papular-Purpuric Gloves and Socks Syndrome:
    • Painful, itchy, and symmetric swelling and erythema of distal hands and feet; may mimic acute meningococcemia. (Option B)

Laboratory Diagnosis
  • PCR: Highly sensitive, detects viral DNA (VP1, VP2 genes) in serum, tissue, or respiratory secretions.
  • ELISA: Detects IgM antibody (early indicator, elevated 2–3 months) and IgG against VP1 and VP2 antigens.
  • Immunohistochemistry: Detects viral antigens in fetal tissues and bone marrow.
  • Bone marrow cytology shows Giant pro-erythroblasts with multiple cytoplasmic projections that look like "dog ears" or "pseudopodia".

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with fever, headache, photophobia, and neck rigidity for the last 2 days. He had undergone a heart transplant one year back and is on immunomodulatory drugs. On microscopy, differential motility was seen, non-motile at 37°C, and motile at 25°C. What is the most likely organism causing this?
questions.explanation:
Listeria monocytogenes

Mode of Transmission
  • Contaminated food
  • Vertical transmission (mother to fetus, during birth)

Common Food Sources
  • Contaminated coleslaw
  • Milk, Soft cheeses
  • "Ready-to-eat" foods (delicatessen meat, uncooked hotdogs)

Age Groups at Risk
  • Neonates
  • Elderly individuals

Increased Risk Factors
  • Use of proton pump inhibitors
  • Pregnant women
  • Immunocompromised individuals

Survival in Food
  • Survives refrigeration (4°C)
  • Found in stored foods (aged soft cheeses, packaged meats, milk, cold salads)

Infection Type
  • Sporadic
  • Outbreaks can occur

Psychrotrophic
  • L. monocytogenes is a psychrotrophic organism with an optimum growth temperature of 30ºC to 37ºC but has the ability to grow at a wide range of temperatures from 1ºC to 45ºC.

Motility
  • Shows Tumbling and Differential motility(motile at 25.C by forming actin rockets, non motile at 37.C)

Pathogenesis
  • Intracellular survival: lysis of phagosome (listeriolysin O)
  • Host cell actin polymerization (cell membrane approach)
  • Direct cell-to-cell spread (listeriopods)

Clinical Manifestations
  • Neonatal listeriosis: Early-onset and late-onset disease
  • Pregnant women:
    • Granulomatosis infantiseptica in baby in 3rd trimester
    • Fetal complications (abortion, preterm delivery)
    • Maternal complications (flu-like symptoms, bacteremia, rarely meningitis)
  • Adults:
    • Bacteremia and meningitis (elderly, >60 years)
    • Immunosuppression- higher risk (steroid therapy, HIV, diabetes, malignancy)
    • Post-kidney transplant meningitis (1-month post-transplant)
    • Gastroenteritis (consumption of contaminated milk, meat, salads)

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of fever for 3 days and general fatigue. Echocardiography revealed vegetations on the valves, and a blood culture was performed. The organism in the culture showed alpha hemolysis on blood agar and was resistant to optochin and bile. Which of the following bacteria is most commonly implicated in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Epidemiology:
  • Dental procedures can introduce Streptococcus viridans into the bloodstream, potentially leading to infective endocarditis.
  • Patients with pre-existing heart conditions, such as valvular heart disease or prosthetic valves, are at higher risk.

Infection Mechanism:
  • Capable of producing biofilms, aiding in adherence to heart valves, and resistance to phagocytosis and antibiotics.
  • Production of extracellular polysaccharides enhances its ability to colonize and persist in host tissues.

Clinical Presentation:
  • Symptoms can include fever, chills, heart murmur, fatigue, and signs of embolic events such as petechiae or splinter hemorrhages.
  • Complications may involve heart failure, systemic embolization, and severe valve dysfunction.

Diagnosis:
  • Blood cultures are essential for identifying the causative organism.
  • Echocardiography (especially transesophageal echocardiography) is used to visualize vegetations on the heart valves

Treatment:
  • Prolonged antibiotic therapy, often involves penicillin or ceftriaxone combined with an aminoglycoside.
  • In some cases, surgical intervention may be necessary to repair or replace damaged valves.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male chronic smoker presents with pain in the fingers for a few months. On examination, gangrenous ulcers were present in the fingers, as shown below. Investigation showed blood glucose and lipid profile within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A) Buerger’s disease

Feature

Details

Definition

Non-atherosclerotic, segmental inflammatory vasculitis affecting small & medium-sized arteries and veins.

Etiology

Strong association with tobacco use (smoking or chewing). Exact cause unknown (likely immune-mediated).

Epidemiology

Young males (20–45 years), most commonly smokers.

More common in Middle East, South Asia.

Pathophysiology
  • Inflammation leads to thrombosis and vascular occlusion.
  • Sparing of proximal arteries (unlike atherosclerosis).
  • Segmental involvement (skip lesions).

Clinical Features
  • Claudication, rest pain (foot, hands).
  • Raynaud’s phenomenon (vasospasm causing colour changes in fingers/toes).
  • Ulcers & gangrene (especially in fingers/toes).
  • Migratory superficial thrombophlebitis (inflamed veins).

Diagnosis
  • Clinical diagnosis (no specific lab tests).
  • Doppler & Angiography → Corkscrew collateral vessels (pathognomonic).
  • Exclusion of other causes (diabetes, atherosclerosis, vasculitis).

Management
  1. Complete smoking cessation (most important).
  2. Vasodilators (e.g., calcium channel blockers for Raynaud’s).
  3. Antiplatelets & anticoagulants (limited benefit).
  4. Pain management (NSAIDs, opioids if needed).
  5. Amputation (for non-healing ulcers or gangrene).

Prognosis

Poor if smoking continues but stabilises with smoking cessation.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with TB and while testing for resistance, he was found to be resistant to Isoniazid, Rifampicin, Amikacin, and Levofloxacin. What is this type of TB called?
questions.explanation:
Category

Description

Drug sensitive TB

Patients are sensitive to 4 TB drugs: R,H,Z,E (Rifampicin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol).

Mono-resistant (MR) (Option A)

Resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.

H-Mono-resistant (H-MR)

Resistant to Isoniazid (H) only.

Rifampicin resistant (RR) (Option D)

Resistant to Rifampicin (R) only.

Multi drug resistant (MDR) (Option B)

Resistant to both Rifampicin (R) & Isoniazid (H).

Poly-Drug resistant (PDR) (Option A)

Resistant to 2 drugs other than Rifampicin (R) & Isoniazid (H).

Pre-Xtensive resistant (pre-XDR)

Any MDR patient (H+R) resistant to any fluoroquinolone.

Extensive resistant (XDR) (Option C)

Any MDR patient (H+R) resistant to any fluoroquinolone and Group 4 drugs (Bedaquiline, Linezolid, Levo/Moxifloxacin).

questions.text: A 30-year-old lactating mother presents with pain in her left breast and a fever. On examination of the affected side, there is localized erythema, warmth, and point tenderness, the fluctuation test is positive. There is mild axillary lymphadenopathy on the affected side and the contralateral breast is normal. Repeated aspirations under antibiotic cover were unsuccessful. A USG done showed fluid collection. What is the management plan for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Breast Abscess

Definition
  • Pus-filled cavity within the breast tissue.

Types
  • Lactational Abscess: Associated with breastfeeding.
  • Non-Lactational Abscess: Occurs in non-lactating women, e.g., periductal mastitis.

Causes and Risk Factors
  • Lactation:
    • Incidence: 3% to 20% in lactating mothers.
    • Common pathogen: Staphylococcus aureus (methicillin-resistant strains in hospital settings).
    • Entry points: Cracked/retracted nipple, blocked lactiferous ducts.
  • Non-Lactation:
    • Often in nulliparous women or post-lactation.
    • Conditions: Periductal mastitis, idiopathic granulomatous mastitis, tubercular mastitis.
    • Smoking and diabetes as risk factors.

Signs and symptoms

Fever, leukocytosis, erythema, pain and tenderness, swelling, malaise, difficulty feeding, enlarged and tender axillary nodes

Diagnosis
  • Ultrasonography:
    • Detects cellulitis, and liquefaction necrosis.
    • Confirms abscess size, location, and loculation.

Treatment
  • Lactational Mastitis:
    • Antibiotics: Anti-staphylococcal (e.g., cloxacillin, flucloxacillin, erythromycin).
    • Breast emptying: Frequent breastfeeding or pumping.
    • Support: Breast support garment, cold compresses, analgesia.
    • Drainage: Ultrasound-guided is preferred over surgical incision. (Option A)
    • Follow-up: Regular clinical and ultrasonographic reviews of culture-based antibiotic modification.
  • Non-Lactational Mastitis:
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics for subareolar infections.
    • Needle aspiration for abscess drainage.
    • Major milk duct excision for complications like sepsis or fistula.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female patient presented with a malar rash, recurrent oral ulcers, and multiple joint pains. She has a relevant past history and does not take any medication. questions.explanation:
Marker/Antibody

Clinical Significance

Anti-Smith (anti-Sm) antibodies

Highly specific for SLE (<30% of patients)

Anti-dsDNA antibodies

Highly specific for SLE (60-70% of patients); correlates with the disease

Antinuclear antibodies (ANA)

Highly sensitive but not specific for SLE

Anti-Ro (SSA) and Anti-La (SSB) antibodies

Found in SLE and Sjögren syndrome; associated with neonatal lupus

Anti-ribosomal-P antibodies

Specific for neuropsychiatric manifestations in SLE

Anti-histone antibodies

Seen in drug-induced lupus; less specific for SLE

Complements C3 and C4

Low levels indicate complement consumption and disease activity

questions.text: Examine the provided graphs depicting various occupational groups and their likelihood of developing fever. Identify the group with the greatest probability of experiencing fever.
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - White-collar jobs

Image

Explanation

Simple Bar Diagram

  • Simple bar diagrams represent the frequency of discrete variables like gender.
  • Discrete variables:These variables take fewer values and no in between values.
    • Examples: Religion, Blood groups

 

​​

Compound Bar Diagram

  • There are gaps (discrete data) represented with multiple bars.
  • It is qualitative in the first quarter.
  • It is a Multiple bar diagram/Compound bar diagram.

 

Component Bar Diagram

  • Same bar has been divided into different components and each component represents its frequency.
  • It is a frequency of discrete variables.
  • It is known as the Component bar diagram.

Histogram

  • It is not a bar diagram.
  • It represents the frequency of continuous variables or quantitative variables.
  • Height is a quantitative or continuous variable (can take many possible values and also in between values)
  • It can be expressed in decimals and there is no gap in between.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the surgery out-patient with a left-sided breast lump, which she noticed on a self-breast examination 3 weeks ago. She has no other complaints. On palpation, the lump seems to be mobile and firm. FNAC is characterized by stromal and epithelial elements with no signs of malignancy. What is the best next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer B) Reassurance and follow-up

Fibroadenoma

Definition
  • Benign tumors arising from the proliferation of glandular tissue in the breast

Prevalence
  • Most common in women aged 15-25 years

Aetiology
  • Believed to be influenced by hormonal fluctuations during reproductive years

Clinical Presentation
  • Painless, firm, rubbery, and mobile lumps
  • Described as feeling like a "marble in the breast"

Diagnosis
  • Triple Assessment: Clinical examination, radiological imaging (ultrasound), tissue sampling (core-needle biopsy)
  • Ultrasound: Helps distinguish fibroadenomas from cysts
  • Core-Needle Biopsy: Provides definitive diagnosis

Treatment
  • Conservative Management: Watchful waiting, regular monitoring
  • Surgical Excision: For larger fibroadenomas, those causing symptoms, or uncertain diagnosis
  • Giant Fibroadenomas: Over 5 cm, may require excision through submammary incision

Prognosis
  • Benign, do not increase risk of breast cancer
  • Growth can vary, influenced by hormonal changes
  • Recurrence is uncommon

Relationship to ANDI
  • Categorised according to ANDI as:
    • Normal: Small fibroadenomas (≤1 cm)
    • Disorder: Larger fibroadenomas (≤3 cm)
    • Disease: Giant fibroadenomas (>3 cm), multiple fibroadenomas
