questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for lipoma 5 weeks ago and now presents with a scar at the incision site, which is limited to the original wound boundaries. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which among the following statements is false regarding the instrument/procedure?

options.label: A
options.text: It is used for termination of pregnancy up to 12 weeks

options.label: B
options.text: Can be done on an OP basis

options.label: C
options.text: The capacity of the syringe is 30 ml

options.label: D
options.text: It created a negative pressure of 600 mmHg

questions.correct_answer: C. The capacity of the syringe is 30 ml
questions.explanation:
Uses of MVA Syringe

Use

Description

Pregnancy Termination
  • MVA syringes are commonly used for the termination of early pregnancies (up to 12 weeks).
  • The syringe is used to aspirate and remove the contents of the uterus.
  • It is a safe and effective method for induced abortion in appropriate settings.

Uterine Evacuation
  • MVA syringes are utilized for uterine evacuation in cases of incomplete miscarriage.
  • The syringe is used to remove retained products of conception from the uterus.

Endometrial Sampling
  • MVA syringes can be employed for endometrial sampling or biopsy procedures.
  • The syringe is used to collect a small sample of the endometrial tissue for diagnostic purposes.
  • It is commonly done to investigate abnormal uterine bleeding or to evaluate fertility issues.

Trimester

Procedure

Description

Image

1st

Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA)
  • MVA is an outpatient surgical abortion procedure used up to 12 weeks of gestation.
  • The procedure involves dilating the cervix and inserting a cannula attached to a manual vacuum aspirator or a 60-mL syringe.
  • The cannula is used to remove retained tissue from the uterus.
  • The approximate pressure is around -610 mmHg.

Electric Vacuum Aspiration (EVA)
  • EVA is similar to MVA.
  • Instead of a manual syringe, it uses an electric pump to generate suction to remove retained products of conception.

 

Dilation and Curettage (D&C)

 
  • D&C is performed up to 12 weeks of gestation by dilating the cervix and using instruments like curettes and suction cannula.
  • MVA and EVA are preferred over sharp D&C for being safer and more efficient.

Karman’s cannula

 

Hegar’s dilator

 

Uterine curette

2nd

Dilation and Evacuation (D&E)
  • D&E is a 2nd-trimester abortion method involving cervical dilation using osmotic dilators. Ovum forceps are then used to remove the pregnancy tissue.
  • Draining amniotic fluid before removing the fetus is crucial to minimize the risk of amniotic fluid embolism during the procedure.

Ovum forceps

Hysterotomy

  • A hysterotomy is a surgical procedure where the uterus is incised to remove the fetus.
  • Reserved for 2nd-trimester abortions where other methods are not feasible or have failed.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with fatigue for the past year. Examination reveals massive splenomegaly. His blood workup shows the following findings: Anemia Total leukocyte count (TLC): 150,000/microliter Peripheral smear: 60% neutrophils, 6% basophils, 4% eosinophils, myeloblasts, myelocytes, and metamyelocytes Myeloid to erythroid ratio: 18:1 What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Genetics

Philadelphia chromosome (t(9;22))

Origin

Myeloid lineage

Etiopathogenesis

BCR-ABL fusion gene causes overactive tyrosine kinase activity and is associated with radiation exposure.

Clinical Features
  • Common in adults, presenting with splenomegaly, fatigue, weight loss, night sweats, and abdominal discomfort.
  • It can progress to a blast crisis with acute leukaemia features.

Diagnosis
  • Bone marrow aspirate to confirm diagnosis
  • FISH to detect BCR-ABL fusion gene product

Management

Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., Imatinib)

1) Chronic phase:
  • Leukocytosis, < 10% blast cells, basophils <20% and monocytosis < 3%

2) Accelerated phase:
  • 10%-19% blasts, ≥ 20% basophils in the peripheral blood or bone marrow
  • Persistent or increasing WBC (>10 × 10^9/L) and splenomegaly, unresponsive to therapy
  • Persistent thrombocytosis (>1000 × 10^9/L), unresponsive to therapy
  • Persistent thrombocytopenia (<100 × 10^9/L) unrelated to therapy
  • This phase often leads to the terminal blast crisis within 6-12 months.

3) Blast Crisis:
  • ≥20% blasts in peripheral blood or bone marrow
  • In 50% of patients, the blast crisis occurs abruptly without an accelerated phase.
  • Extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis occurs to compensate for CML and leads to significant splenomegaly.
  • Transformation into AML is more predominant than ALL.

Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL)

 

  • Lymphoblasts in bone marrow >=20%
  • Cytoplasmic vacuolations
  • They contain fat (Oil Red O Positive)
  • Hand mirror-shaped cells

 

Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)

  • Blasts ≥ 20%
  • Myeloblasts with AuerRods

 

3. Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL):

  • Smudge cells (or parachute/basket cell): Due to the fragility of lymphocytes during slide preparation
  • Convent Girl Appearance: Lot of homogenous, small, mature-like, round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm

Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML)

  • Leukocytosis
  • Cell Types: Neutrophils( multilobed nucleus), metamyelocytes (indented nucleus), myelocytes (D-shaped nucleus), and eosinophils (orange cells)
  • College girl/garden party appearance: Due to the variety of cell appearances
  • Shift to the Left: Presence of immature cell types, mainly immature neutrophils, in the blood.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 23-year-old woman who is pregnant for the first time, currently at 25 weeks gestation, and experiencing pain in the right upper quadrant of her abdomen, along with nausea and vomiting for the past two days? Her blood pressure is 104/72 mm Hg, heart rate is 72 bpm, and she has generalized swelling. A peripheral smear shows hemolysis, and the following lab values are provided:Leukocyte count: 10,500/mm3 Platelet count: 62000/mm3 Hematocrit: 26% AST: 90 IU/L
questions.explanation:
Haemolysis
  • Abnormal peripheral blood smear (Hemolysis)
  • Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH > 600 IU/L)
  • Elevated bilirubin (≥ 1.2 mg/dL)
  • Decreased serum haptoglobin

Elevated Liver Enzymes
  • Elevated (AST & ALT > 70 IU/L)

Low Platelet Count
  • Platelets < 100,000/μL

Mississippi Triple Class System

Class I (severe)
  • AST & ALT > 70 IU/L
  • LDH > 600 IU/L
  • Platelets <50 x 109 /L

Class II (moderate)
  • AST & ALT > 70 IU/L
  • LDH > 600 IU/L
  • Platelets 50-100 x 109 /L

Class III (mild)
  • AST & ALT > 40 IU/L
  • LDH > 600 IU/L
  • Platelets 100-150 x 109 /L

Condition

HELLP Syndrome

Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy (AFLP)

Intrahepatic Cholestasis of Pregnancy (ICP)

Main Characteristics

Hemolysis (breakdown of red blood cells), Elevated liver enzymes, Low Platelet count

Buildup of fat in the liver, liver dysfunction

Impaired bile flow, elevated bile acids, itching

Occurrence

Usually occurs in the third trimester, but can also occur postpartum

Typically occurs in the third trimester

Usually occurs in the third trimester, but can occur earlier

Symptoms

Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, headache, edema

Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, jaundice, malaise

Intense itching, especially on palms and soles

Risk to Mother

Can lead to serious complications such as liver rupture, liver failure, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)

Can lead to liver failure, coagulopathy, and other complications

Generally uncomfortable but usually does not pose a significant threat to the mother's overall health

Risk to Fetus

Can lead to fetal growth restriction, preterm birth, stillbirth, placental abruption

Can lead to fetal distress, preterm birth, and stillbirth

Increased risk of adverse fetal outcomes, such as preterm birth or stillbirth

Management

Immediate medical attention required, delivery of the baby may be necessary

Urgent medical intervention required, delivery of the baby may be necessary

Symptom relief, monitoring of bile acid levels, early delivery may be considered

Complications

Liver rupture, liver failure, DIC, maternal and fetal mortality

Liver failure, coagulopathy, maternal and fetal mortality

Increased risk of preterm birth, fetal distress, stillbirth

HELLP Syndrome

Risk Factors
  • History of preeclampsia or HELLP syndrome
  • Multiparity
  • Advanced maternal age
  • Obesity
  • Diabetes
  • Chronic hypertension

Clinical Features
  • Right upper quadrant or epigastric pain
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Malaise
  • Headache & visual disturbances
  • Hypertension
  • Proteinuria

Complications

Mother:

  • Liver hematoma or rupture
  • Acute renal failure
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
  • Placental abruption

Fetus:

  • Preterm birth
  • IUGR or Stillbirth

A 1-month-old child is brought to the OPD for consultation regarding an empty scrotal sac. On examination B/L inguinal masses are palpable. What is the next step of management for this child?

options.text: Surgical exploration within the next 2 weeks

options.text: Wait and watch for spontaneous descent within the next 6 months.

questions.correct_answer: D. Wait and watch for spontaneous descent within the next 6 months.
questions.explanation:
Correct answer D) Wait and watch for spontaneous descent within the next 6 months

Undescended Testis (Cryptorchidism)

Definition

Cryptorchidism is a condition where one or both testes fail to descend into the scrotum from the abdomen.

Locations
  • Inguinal/Palpable undescended testis: 80%
  • Abdominal/Non-Palpable undescended testis: 20%

Causes and Associated Conditions
  • Developmental and Genetic Factors: Conditions like Klinefelter syndrome and testosterone imbalances can impair testicular descent.
  • Prematurity and Maternal Factors: Premature birth and maternal issues like diabetes or medication exposure can lead to undescended testes.
  • Mechanical and Physical Factors: Obstructions in the inguinal canal, scrotum, or related conditions such as inguinal hernia can prevent normal testicular descent.

Complications

(SATHI Mnemonic):

  • S: Sterility - Elevated abdominal temperature can impair sperm production, leading to potential infertility if untreated.
  • A: Atrophy - Prolonged exposure to heat can cause the testis to shrink or become non-functional.
  • T: Trauma, Tumor, Torsion - Increased risk of testicular torsion, which can cause severe pain and potentially result in testicular loss. The most common tumor associated is seminoma with the highest risk of tumor development in abdominal testes.
  • H: Hernia - Over 90% of cases are associated with a patent processus vaginalis, increasing the risk of inguinal hernia.
  • I: Inflammation - The undescended testis is more prone to inflammatory conditions.

Note: Leydig cells are unaffected, maintaining secondary sexual characteristics, while Sertoli cells are impaired, affecting spermatogenesis.

Diagnosis
  • Palpable undescended testis: Inguinal exploration.
  • Non-Palpable undescended testis: Diagnostic laparoscopy.
  • Imaging: Ultrasound or MRI may be utilized to locate the testis.

Treatment

Surgical Repositioning (Orchidopexy): Usually performed when the child is between 6-12 months old. (Option D)

Types of Orchidopexy

  • Ombridannes
  • Keetley-Torek
  • Stephen-Fowler
  • Ladd & Gross

questions.text: A patient who underwent surgery for a lipoma 5 weeks ago now presents with a scar at the incision site that is limited to the original wound boundaries. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer C) Hypertrophic scar

Feature

Hypertrophic Scar

Keloid

Exuberant Granulation ("Proud Flesh")

Granulation Tissue

Definition

Excess collagen deposition leading to a raised scar within wound boundaries.

(Option D ruled out )

Excess collagen deposition extending beyond the wound. (Option A ruled out )

Overgrowth of granulation tissue above skin level. (Option B ruled out )

Early vascularized tissue forming during wound healing. (Option C)

Wound Boundaries

Confined to the original wound.

Extends beyond the wound margins.

Protrudes beyond the skin level.

Confined to wound, but not raised.

Onset

Weeks after injury.

Months after injury.

Early post-injury phase.

Forms within days of injury.

Resolution

May regress over time.

Persists and grows continuously.

Requires treatment (cauterization or excision).

Normal component of healing.

Common Locations

Areas of high tension (joints, chest, back).

Earlobes, shoulders, chest, upper arms.

Open wounds, surgical sites.

Any healing wound.

Histology

Collagen organized parallel to skin surface.

Disorganized, excessive collagen deposition.

Excess granulation tissue, rich in capillaries.

Fibroblasts, capillaries, and inflammatory cells.

Treatment

Pressure therapy, steroids, laser therapy (if symptomatic).

Intralesional steroids, cryotherapy, excision (high recurrence).

Silver nitrate cautery, surgical trimming.

No treatment needed (normal part of healing).

questions.text: Xenograft is:
questions.explanation:
Type of Graft

Description

Autograft

An organ or tissue is taken from an individual and grafted on him/ herself

(Option C ruled out)

Isograft

Grafts between genetically identical individuals, such as identical twins

(Option D ruled out)

Allograft

Graft between two genetically non-identical members of the same species (e.g. organ transplants between two non-identical and compatible individuals. (Option B ruled out)

Xenograft

Graft from one species to another (e.g., pig skin is a temporary substitute for burn treatment). (Option A)

Synthetic Graft

Artificial materials or bioengineered constructs replace or support damaged tissue (e.g., artificial skin substitutes, bone graft substitutes).

questions.text: A postmenopausal woman presented with pain in her lower abdomen for the past 4 months. She has had fibroids for a long time. The radiological investigation is shown below. What is the type of degeneration that occurred in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Type of Change

Pathophysiology

Microscopic/Gross Findings

Clinical Pearls

Hyaline Degeneration

(65% - Most Common) (Option B)
  • Decreased blood supply
  • Accumulation of extracellular proteins
  • More common in tumors with high connective tissue content
  • Cut surface: Irregular homogeneous areas
  • Loss of whorl-like appearance
  • Microscopy: Hyaline changes of both muscle and fibrous tissue
  • Most common type
  • Can occur at any stage
  • Usually asymptomatic

Red Degeneration

(5-10%)
  • Hemorrhagic infarction
  • Occurs during pregnancy
  • Vascular origin
  • Venous thrombosis
  • Dark red appearance
  • Raw-beef appearance on cut section
  • Fishy odor (fatty acids)
  • Hemorrhagic areas with thrombosed vessels
  • High-yield: Associated with pregnancy
  • Acute pain common
  • Partial recovery possible
  • Important in differential of pregnancy pain

Cystic Degeneration

(Option D)
  • Follows hyaline change
  • Liquefactive necrosis
  • Common in interstitial fibroids
  • Fluid-filled spaces
  • Irregular cystic areas
  • May be confused with pregnancy on ultrasound
  • Can mimic pregnancy on imaging
  • Important radiological differential
  • More common in larger fibroids

Calcific Degeneration

(10%) (Option C)
  • Usually follows fatty degeneration
  • Calcium/phosphate deposition
  • Common in postmenopausal women
  • "Womb stone" formation
  • Dense calcified mass
  • Radio-opaque on imaging
  • High-yield: Associated with menopause
  • Visible on plain X-ray
  • Often small and pedunculated

Myxomatous Degeneration

(15%)
  • Central part involvement
  • Smooth muscle cell changes
  • Mucoid accumulation
  • Gelatinous appearance
  • Mainly affects central portions
  • Smooth muscle degeneration
  • Less commonly tested
  • Can affect tumor size
  • May alter imaging characteristics

Fatty Degeneration (Option A)
  • Occurs at/after menopause
  • Fat globule deposition in muscle cells
  • Often precedes calcification
  • Fat globules in muscle cells
  • May show lipid-laden cells
  • Often focal distribution
  • Associated with postmenopausal status
  • Can precede calcification
  • Usually asymptomatic

Sarcomatous Change

(<0.1%)
  • Malignant transformation
  • Risk factors: rapid growth
  • Postmenopausal bleeding
  • Sudden enlargement
  • Irregular margins
  • Necrosis and hemorrhage
  • High-yield: Very rare but important
  • Red flag: rapid growth in postmenopausal woman
  • Requires immediate evaluation

Atrophic Changes
  • Loss of estrogen support
  • Postmenopausal change
  • Reduction in cellularity
  • Size reduction
  • Decreased cellularity
  • Increased fibrosis
  • Expected finding after menopause
  • May help with symptoms
  • Natural evolution

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for a 3-year-old child with amblyopia in the right eye?
questions.correct_answer: C. Occlusion of the left eye
questions.explanation:
Amblyopia treatment should be started as early as possible (younger the child, better the prognosis). Amblyopia therapy works best when initiated in young children under 3 years of age and comprise:

Occlusion therapy (Option C): Occlusion of the sound (normal) eye to force use of amblyopic eye is the main stay in the treatment of amblyopia. Following methods are deployed,

  • Full-time occlusion: Up to 2 years, the occlusion should be done in 2:1, i.e. 2 days in sound eye and one day in amblyopic eye; at the age of 3 years, 3:1; at the age of 4 years, 4:1; At the age of 5 years, 5:1; and after the age of 6 years 6:1.
  • Part-time occlusion: 4-6 hours/day, as shown by Amblyopia Treatment Study (ATS), and is as effective as full-time occlusion.
  • Maintenance occlusion: After vision equalization, part-time occlusion continues until at least 8 years of age.
  • Ensure no media opacity or refractive errors before starting occlusion therapy.

Other Methods:

  • Penalization: Blurring vision in the sound eye with atropine or over-plus lenses.
  • Computerized Home Vision Therapy: Uses specially designed software as an adjunct to occlusion therapy.
  • Pharmacologic Manipulation
    • Levodopa/Carbidopa: Studied as an adjunct to occlusion therapy.
    • Other agents: Citicoline and omega fatty acids
  • Pleoptics: Pleoptic exercises are done to improve foveal fixation, though less commonly used now.

questions.text: What would be your approach in managing a patient who is a 40-year-old woman with a 5 mm gallbladder polyp detected on abdominal ultrasound, but no gallbladder stones? The patient is overall healthy and shows no symptoms.
questions.explanation:
Correct answer A) Regular follow-up every 2 months:

Polyp Size

Management

<6 mm

Regular follow-up (USG every 6–12 months for 2 years)

6–9 mm

Follow-up every 3–6 months, consider cholecystectomy if growth or risk factors

≥10 mm

Laparoscopic cholecystectomy (higher malignancy risk)

Any size + symptoms or high-risk features

questions.text: Match the given images to their descriptions: 1. A. Posterior subcapsular cataract 2. B. Sunflower cataract 3. C. Morgagnian cataract 4. D. Snowflake cataract
questions.explanation:
1.

B) Sunflower cataract:

  • Deposition of copper under the posterior capsule of the lens.
  • Cause: Wilson's disease

 

2.

C) Morgagnian cataract:

  • Seen in hypermature senile cataract
  • Cortex liquefies
  • Nucleus sinks to the bottom
  • Bag of milky fluid appearance

3.

D) Snowflake cataract:

  • Also known as snowburst cataract
  • Cause: Diabetes mellitus

 

4.

A) Posterior subcapsular cataract:

  • Opacity below the capsule in the central part of the posterior cortex.
  • Causes:
    • Complicated cataract
    • Blunt trauma
    • Myotonic dystrophy (Christmas tree cataract)
    • Glactosemia (Oil droplet cataract)
    • Drugs: Steroid, chloroquine, busulfan

 

Type of Cataract

Characteristics

Visual Impact

Cuneiform Senile Cortical Cataract
  • Wedge-shaped opacities with clear areas in between.
  • Extends from periphery to center.
  • First appears in the lower nasal quadrant. Present in both anterior and posterior cortex.
  • The radial spoke-like pattern of opacities is seen.
  • Visual disturbances are noted at a comparatively late stage (since it starts at the periphery).
  • Vision improves in bright light with contracted pupils.

Cupuliform Senile Cortical Cataract

 
  • Saucer-shaped opacities are typically in the central part of the posterior cortex (posterior subcapsular cataract).
  • Extends from center to periphery.
  • Causes an early loss of visual acuity.- Due to the involvement of the nodal point
  • Glares seen in PSC
  • Better vision in dim light with dilated pupils.

Stage

Description

Characteristics

1. Stage of Lamellar Separation

Earliest stage of senile cataract
  • Formation of vacuoles and water clefts within the cortex
  • Reversible change
  • Can only be demonstrated by slit lamp examination

2. Stage of Incipient Cataract

Detectable opacities with clear areas present between. Causes visual disturbances.

Cuneiform type:

  • Wedge-shaped opacities, extending from the equator appear as radial spoke-like opacities.

Cupuliform type:

  • Saucer-shaped opacity in the central posterior cortex.

3. Immature Senile Cataract

Progression of opacification
  • Iris shadow visible (clear cortex visible) -Iris Shadow present here due to opacities + clear areas
  • Can progress to Intumescent Cataract leading to the shallow anterior chamber.

4. Mature Senile Cataract (aka intumescent cataract)

Complete opacification of cortex
  • The lens appears pearly white
  • Referred to as a "ripe cataract"
  • No iris shadow as the whole lens is opacified with a chalky white color

5. Hypermature Senile Cataract (HMSC)

Advanced stage of cataract beyond maturity

Morgagnian Hypermature Cataract:

  • Cortex liquefies
  • Nucleus sinks to the bottom
  • Bag of milky fluid appearance

Sclerotic Hypermature Cataract:

  • The cortex disintegrates, lens and capsule shrink.
  • Deep anterior chamber
  • Iridodonesis may be present.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common side effect of cholecystectomy?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer C) Steatorrhea

Category

Complication

Description/Features

Early (Intraoperative & Immediate Postoperative)

Bile Duct Injury

Accidental damage to the common bile duct (CBD) leads to bile leakage or strictures (More common in laparoscopic cholecystectomy).

Hemorrhage

Bleeding from the cystic artery or liver bed; managed with hemostasis or blood transfusion if severe.

Bowel Injury

Unintended injury to the duodenum or colon, is rare but serious.

Anesthesia-related Complications

Aspiration, respiratory depression, hypotension, and arrhythmias.

Early Postoperative (0–7 Days)

Infection (Wound/Port-Site Abscess)

Fever, erythema, tenderness at the incision site. More common in diabetics or immunocompromised patients.

Bile Leak (Biloma)

Fever, abdominal pain, nausea, and localized fluid collection on imaging. Often from cystic duct stump or accessory bile duct injury.

Subhepatic Collection (Abscess)

Fever, RUQ pain, and tachycardia; requires percutaneous drainage.

Retained Gallstones

Residual gallstones in the bile duct can cause biliary colic or cholangitis postoperatively.

Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) & Pulmonary Embolism (PE)

Due to prolonged immobilization, leading to leg swelling or sudden dyspnea (Prevent with early ambulation, anticoagulation).

Late Postoperative (>7 Days – Months/Years)

Steatorrhea (Fatty Stools)

(Option C)

Most common long-term issue due to continuous bile secretion, leading to fat malabsorption.

Post-Cholecystectomy Syndrome (PCS)

Persistent dyspepsia, bloating, diarrhea, or RUQ pain due to bile reflux or remnant stones.

Biliary Strictures

Chronic narrowing of the CBD, leading to jaundice and cholangitis.

Chronic Diarrhea

Related to altered bile acid metabolism, may require bile acid sequestrants (e.g., cholestyramine).

Increased Risk of Colorectal Cancer (Debatable)

Some studies suggest a mild increase in colon cancer risk due to altered bile acid metabolism, but evidence is weak.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate treatment for a 55-year-old woman who is experiencing long-term mucopurulent discharge from her left eye and swelling near the inner corner of the eye?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Acute Dacryocystitis

Chronic Dacryocystitis

Aetiology
  • Acute exacerbation of chronic dacryocystitis
  • Spread from neighbouring infected structures (e.g., sinuses, bones, dental abscess)
  • Causative organisms: Streptococcus haemolyticus, Pneumococcus, Staphylococcus
  • Stasis and mild infection of long duration
  • Common in women aged 40-60
  • Causes: anatomical factors (narrow bony canal), nasal diseases, foreign bodies, infection.

Clinical Features/ Sequelae
  1. Stage of cellulitis: Painful swelling at the lacrimal sac, epiphora, fever, redness, and oedema.
  2. Lacrimal abscess: Pus-filled sac, fluctuant swelling, may rupture forming an abscess.
  3. Fistula formation: Untreated abscess leads to spontaneous discharge, forming a fistula.
  1. Stage of chronic catarrhal dacryocystitis: Watering eye, mild redness, NLD block
  2. Lacrimal mucocele: Swelling below inner canthus, mucoid fluid regurgitation.
  3. Chronic suppurative dacryocystitis: Purulent discharge (d/t infection), recurrent conjunctivitis.
  1. Chronic fibrotic sac: Thickened mucosa, persistent epiphora, irregular folds.

Image

Complications

Conjunctivitis, corneal ulcer, lid abscess, orbital cellulitis, facial cellulitis, rarely cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Conjunctivitis, ectropion of lower lid, risk of corneal ulcers.

Treatment
  • Cellulitis: Systemic antibiotics, anti-inflammatory drugs, hot fomentation.
  • Lacrimal abscess: Drainage with incision, antibiotics, possible DCT or DCR later. (Option C)
  • External fistula: Fistulectomy with DCT or DCR after controlling infection.
  • Conservative: Probing and syringing (early stages).
  • Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR): Preferred surgery to re-establish lacrimal drainage. (Option A)
  • Dacryocystectomy (DCT): Indicated if DCR is contraindicated or in cases of fibrosis, infection, or old age (>60y). (Option B)

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for breastfeeding?

options.label: D
options.text: Infants born to an HbsAg-positive mother

questions.correct_answer: B. Classic galactosemia in the infant
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Classic galactosemia in the infant

Breastfeeding Contraindications

Maternal Contraindications

Infectious Diseases:

 

Active Tuberculosis

Mothers with active tuberculosis should delay breastfeeding until they have completed at least two weeks of appropriate treatment to reduce the risk of transmission.

Active Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) Lesions on the Breast:

Breastfeeding is contraindicated if a mother has active herpetic lesions on her breast to prevent transmission to the infant.

Varicella-Zoster Infection

If the mother has active chickenpox lesions, breastfeeding should be avoided to prevent direct contact between the lesions and the infant. The infant should also receive appropriate immunoglobulin.

Medications and Treatments:

Chemotherapy, Radiopharmaceuticals and Certain Medications
  • Breastfeeding is usually contraindicated during maternal treatment with chemotherapy or radiopharmaceuticals due to the potential harm to the infant.
  • Specific medications, such as some anticoagulants, anti-tuberculosis drugs, and anticonvulsants, may require mothers to avoid breastfeeding.

Substance Use: Alcohol and Smoking

(Option A)

  • While not a strict contraindication, alcohol consumption should be limited to less than 0.5g/kg/day.
  • Cigarette smoking is strongly discouraged.

Maternal Health Conditions:

  • Severe Illness or Surgery
  • Breast Conditions
  • Maternal issues like mastitis or breast engorgement may complicate breastfeeding and require temporary cessation but are not absolute contraindications.

Fetal Contraindications

Metabolic Disorders: Galactosemia

Infants with galactosemia, a condition where they cannot process galactose, should not be breastfed. Instead, they require specialized formulas.

Anatomical Challenges: Oral or Facial Anomalies

Conditions like cleft palate that affect the infant's ability to suckle may necessitate alternative feeding methods.

Prematurity or Low Birth Weight: Support Needs

Premature or low-birth-weight infants may initially require supplemental feeding methods until they can effectively breastfeed.

questions.text: Which of the following surgeries use this instrument?
In the case presented, can you identify the imaging technique employed and the specific diagnosis related to the kidneys?
questions.correct_answer: A. MRI of polycystic kidney disease
questions.explanation:
Imaging Modality

Findings

Indications

Ultrasound (USG)

Enlarged kidneys, multiple cysts

First-line screening in suspected PKD

CT Scan

Multiple cysts, hemorrhage, infection

Detects complications like rupture or infection

MRI

High-resolution imaging of cysts, no radiation

Preferred for assessing renal function and disease progression

Plain Radiograph
  • Enlarged, multilobulated renal outlines with bowel displacement.
  • Multiple calcifications, sometimes with multiple ring appearance.
  • Intravenous urography: "Swiss cheese nephrogram" (due to multiple renal cysts), "Spiderleg pyelogram" (stretched pelvicalyceal system).

Ultrasound
  • Simple cysts: Anechoic with thin walls, posterior acoustic enhancement, and lateral shadowing.
  • Complicated cysts (haemorrhage/infection): Echogenic material within the cyst, possible wall calcification, absence of internal blood flow.
  • CEUS: Demonstrates enhancement

CT
  • Simple cysts: Rounded with near-water attenuation and thin walls.
  • Complications (haemorrhage/infection): Higher attenuation and wall calcification.

CT showing ADPKD

 

MRI
  • T2 MRI- The most sensitive imaging modality
  • Both enlarged kidneys have multiple cysts

MRI showing ADPKD

questions.text: In what situation is popcorn calcification observed?

A child was brought to the emergency room, with a fever for 2 days, dyspnea, drooling and inspiratory stridor. Lateral x-ray neck findings were as seen below. Which is the most common organism (in India) that causes this condition in children?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Haemophilus influenza B

Acute Epiglottitis

Life-threatening infection that causes profound swelling of the upper airways, which can lead to asphyxia and respiratory arrest.

Causative Agent

  • Past Era (Pre-vaccine): Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib)
  • Post-vaccine Era:
    • Streptococcus pneumoniae (M/c), Streptococcus pyogenes, non-typeable H. influenzae (Option B), and Staphylococcus aureus (Option C)
    • Hib cases have decreased by 99% due to widespread vaccination

Clinical Features
  • High fever
  • Sore throat
  • Dyspnea
  • Respiratory obstruction
  • Respiratory distress
  • The child appears toxic
  • Difficulty swallowing
  • Labored breathing
  • Drooling
  • Neck hyperextension to maintain airway
  • Tripod position (sitting upright, leaning forward)
  • Stridor is a late sign indicating near-complete airway obstruction
  • Cyanosis
  • Coma

Diagnosis

  • Laryngoscopy: Large, cherry-red, swollen epiglottis
  • Lateral neck X-ray: Thumb sign

Treatment

  • Immediate Treatment:
    • Secure the airway with endotracheal or nasotracheal intubation or, less often, with tracheostomy.
    • Intubation is generally for 2-3 days.
    • Intubation decreases mortality from 6% to <1% in epiglottitis cases.
    • Culture Collection: Blood, epiglottic surface and CSF in certain cases after the airway is stabilized.
  • Antibiotics: Ceftriaxone, cefepime or meropenem given parenterally for 10 days.

Recovery

Symptoms improve with a few days of antibiotics, and the patient may be extubated.

questions.text: A young man presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal pain and 3 episodes of vomiting in the past 9 hours. He says that the pain radiates to the back and is partially relieved by bending forwards. The abdominal radiograph of the patient is given below which shows a ‘colon cut-off sign ’. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer B) Acute pancreatitis

Feature

Description

Definition

Acute inflammation of the pancreas due to premature enzyme activation, leads to autodigestion.

Common Causes (Mnemonic: "I GET SMASHED")

Idiopathic, Gallstones (most common), Ethanol, Trauma, Steroids, Mumps, Autoimmune, Scorpion sting, Hyperlipidemia/hypercalcemia, ERCP, Drugs (thiazides, azathioprine).

Clinical Features

Severe epigastric pain (radiates to back, worsens after food), nausea, vomiting, fever. Severe cases: Cullen’s Sign (periumbilical bruising), Grey Turner’s Sign (flank bruising), Colon Cutoff Sign (gas-filled, distended transverse colon with abrupt cut-off at splenic flexure due to inflammation).(Option B)

Diagnosis (Atlanta Criteria)

≥2 of 3 criteria: (1) Lipase >3x ULN (more specific than amylase), (2) Epigastric pain, (3) Imaging (CT/USG/MRI) evidence. CT scan (best for complications), Ultrasound (detects gallstones).

Severity Classification

Mild: No organ failure, Moderate: <48 hrs organ failure, Severe: >48 hrs organ failure.

Management

IV Fluids (Ringer’s lactate), NPO (Bowel Rest), Pain Control (IV opioids), and Enteral feeding are preferred over TPN. ERCP only if gallstone pancreatitis with cholangitis. No routine antibiotics unless infected necrosis.

Complications

Early (<1 week): SIRS, Shock, ARDS, Renal failure, DIC, Hypocalcemia. Late (>1 week): Necrosis (sterile/infected), Pseudocyst, Abscess, Chronic Pancreatitis, Biliary obstruction.

questions.text: What is the likely cause of sudden loss of vision in the left eye for the past two hours in a 58-year-old man who experienced it after his retirement party? The fundoscopic examination reveals a similar image shown below.
questions.explanation:
Risk Factors
  • Atherosclerosis
  • Age
  • Hypertension/Cardiac Diseases
  • Thrombophilic Disorders
  • Smoking
  • Diabetes Mellitus
  • Oral Contraceptive Pills

Clinical Features

Symptoms:

  • Sudden, painless, profound vision loss.
  • Painful only in GCA: May present with headache, jaw claudication, scalp tenderness, and/or pain around the temple.

 

Clinical Signs:

  • Severely reduced Visual Acuity (VA), often to counting fingers or worse.
  • Profound and sometimes total Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect (RAPD), also called an amaurotic pupil.

Examination Findings

Fundus Examination:

  • Retinal Whitening: Pale and opaque retina, particularly in the posterior pole.
  • Cherry-Red Spot: Bright red area at the fovea due to the contrast between pale retina and underlying choroidal circulation.
  • Cattle Truck Appearance: Segmentation of the blood column in retinal veins.
  • Attenuated Arteries: Narrowed and segmented retinal arterioles.
  • Optic Disc Changes: Pale optic disc over time due to optic atrophy from prolonged ischemia (chronic cases).

Investigations

Fluorescein Angiography (FFA):

  • Delayed arterial filling.
  • Masking of background fluorescence due to edematous retina.
  • Patent Cilioretinal Artery: Area of normal perfusion of a cilioretinal artery supplies the fovea, potentially preserving central vision.

Other Diagnostic Tests:

  • Retinal edema, structural changes, and possibly an embolic plaque within the retinal artery.
  • Cranial MRI or CT.
  • Carotid duplex scanning.
  • Echocardiography.

Management
  • Smoking cessation
  • Ocular massage
  • IOP control agents: Acetazolamide
  • Hyperosmotics: Mannitol
  • Carbogen (95% O2 + 5% CO2) inhalation
  • Nd-YAG laser embolectomy

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of radiolucent renal stone?
questions.explanation:
Stone Type

Features

Image

Calcium Oxalate
  • The most common type of stone (60–85% of all stones); Radiopaque
  • Associated with hypercalciuria, hypercalcaemia, hyperoxaluria, hyperuricosuria, and hypocitraturia
  • Types: monohydrate (dumbbell-shaped) , dihydrate (envelope shaped)

​

​​​

​​

Calcium Phosphate
  • Pure calcium phosphate stones are rare
  • Types include apatite and brushite stones
  • Apatite stones are seen with infection; brushite stones are associated with distal renal tubular acidosis.

​

​​

Struvite
  • Aka staghorn calculi / Triple phosphate stone (Ca, Mg, NH4+, Phosphate)
  • Radiopaque
  • Infection stones that form in alkaline urine due to urease-producing bacteria (e.g., Proteus, Klebsiella, Serratia, Enterobacter)

​​

​​ ​​

Cystine
  • Radiopaque, Constitute approximately 1% of stones
  • Result from cystinuria, an autosomal recessive inherited disease that causes decreased reabsorption of cystine.
  • Very hard stones due to disulfide bonds

Uric Acid
  • Radiolucent
  • Promoted by hyperuricosuria, which can be caused by conditions like gout and myeloproliferative disorders
  • Precipitates in acidic urine and remains soluble in alkaline urine.

​

questions.text: The probable cause for a patient with a corneal scar having a visual acuity of 6/36, which improves to 6/18 with a pinhole, is most likely due to...
questions.explanation:
Pinhole Test

Stenopeic Slit Test

Mechanism

Uses a small opaque disc with holes to reduce retinal blur and improve visual acuity in refractive errors up to 4D.

Uses a narrow slit to reduce peripheral aberrations and enhance depth of focus.

 

Clinical Applications
  • Determines if reduced vision is due to refractive errors; vision improvement suggests a refractive issue. (Option C)
  • Quick assessment of visual acuity, often in under-resourced settings.
  • WHO recommended blindness surveys.
  • To assess astigmatism, especially irregular astigmatism (as it allows for a more detailed analysis of the patient's visual field by focusing light along a single axis) or complex visual issues.
  • A stenopeic slit is used in cases of corneal opacities to help identify the best location for an optical iridectomy.

Limitations
  • Can underestimate post-refractive visual acuity.
  • Reduces light reaching the retina, potentially causing diffraction blur.
  • Limited mainly to complex refractive issues.

questions.text: For which of the following conditions is the Whitaker test recommended?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer A) Hydronephrosis

Feature

Details

Definition

A urodynamic test that measures the pressure gradient between the renal pelvis and bladder to assess upper urinary tract obstruction.

Indications

Equivocal cases of upper urinary tract obstruction, PUJ obstruction, post-pyeloplasty evaluation, distinguishing true obstruction from hydronephrosis.

Procedure

1. Percutaneous nephrostomy placed in the renal pelvis.

2. Bladder catheter inserted for pressure measurement.

3. Fluid infusion into renal pelvis at 10 ml/min.

4. Pressure difference between renal pelvis & bladder recorded.

Interpretation

<15 cm H₂O → No obstruction.

15–22 cm H₂O → Indeterminate (needs further evaluation).

>22 cm H₂O → Significant obstruction present.

Advantages

Helps differentiate true obstruction vs. non-obstructive dilation.

Useful in post-surgical cases.

Limitations

Invasive (rarely used due to modern imaging).

Replaced by diuretic renal scan (DTPA/EC scan) & MR Urography.

questions.text: A child presents to your outpatient department with the findings shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Kwashiorkor

Kwashiorkor

Marasmus (Option B)

Pitting Edema: Characterized by swelling, often starting in the legs and feet, leaving a persistent indentation when pressed.

Absence of Edema: Unlike kwashiorkor, marasmus does not involve swelling or oedema.

Sugar Baby Appearance: The child may look deceptively healthy due to oedema, despite being malnourished.

Monkey Facies: A sunken appearance of the cheeks due to loss of fat, giving an aged look.

Muscle Wasting: Despite the swollen appearance, muscle loss is present, leading to weakness and hypotonia.

Severe Wasting: The child appears extremely thin, with prominent bones and little body fat.

Mental and Neurological Symptoms: The child is apathetic, irritable, and may have feeding difficulties.

Alertness: Children with marasmus remain mentally alert.

Hair Changes: Hair may lose colour, become thin, and show alternating bands of colour ("flag sign").

Baggy Pants Appearance: Loose, sagging skin around the buttocks caused by significant muscle and fat loss.

Skin Changes: Includes hyperpigmentation, peeling skin ("flaky paint" appearance), and colour changes, particularly in the buttocks, perineum, and thighs.

Hypoglycemia Risk: The liver's reduced capacity to produce glucose increases the risk of low blood sugar.

Gastrointestinal Issues: Anorexia, vomiting, and abdominal distension. Anaemia is present due to nutritional deficiencies.

Hypothermia Risk: The child may struggle to maintain body temperature due to energy depletion.

questions.text: The following image is of the most common cause of stridor in children. Identify it.
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Laryngomalacia

Laryngomalacia

Definition
  • M/c congenital laryngeal anomaly in children; characterized by floppy tissues above the vocal cords that collapse during inspiration, causing stridor.
  • Accounts for 45% to 75% of stridor cases in infants.

Onset

Appear within the first 2 weeks of life and can worsen for up to six months, with gradual improvement often occurring thereafter.

Factors deciding severity and clinical course
  • Gastroesophageal reflux disease
  • Laryngopharyngeal reflux disease
  • Neurological conditions

Investigations
  • Diagnosis is made mainly by clinical symptoms.
  • Outpatient flexible laryngoscopy is done to confirm the diagnosis but is not suitable for a baby as well as when dysphagia is suspected.
  • Laryngoscopy sows the omega sign: The inward curling of the epiglottis to become omega-shaped.
  • Airway films and chest radiographs are done when the work of breathing is moderate to severe.
  • A contrast swallow study or Flexible endoscopic evaluation of swallowing (FEES) is considered when dysphagia is suspected.
  • Complete bronchoscopy is done for those with moderate to severe obstruction.

Treatment
  • Expectant observation for most infants as the spontaneous resolution of symptoms as the child grows is seen.
  • Laryngoesophageal reflux and GERD are treated with proton pump inhibitors or histamine receptor antagonists, considering the possible iron deficiency anaemia.
  • Supraglottoplasty is done in case of severe disease that causes progressive respiratory distress, cyanosis, failure to thrive, or cor pulmonale.
  • Earlier intervention is needed in children with cardiac disease, neurologic disease, pulmonary disorders, or craniofacial anomalies.

questions.text: A newborn infant is brought to the pediatric clinic due to the presence of a sac-like protrusion on the lower back. The protrusion is covered by a thin membrane and contains spinal cord tissue and nerves. The infant's lower limbs exhibit weakness and impaired sensation. The mother reports inadequate prenatal folic acid intake during pregnancy. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Spina bifida

Category

Details

Definition

Failure of proper closure of neural tube & covering mesoderm/ectoderm; most common congenital CNS anomaly.

Inheritance

Primary NTDs have multifactorial inheritance.

Maternal risk factors

Alcohol, radiation exposure, IDDM, valproate, carbamazepine, zinc and folate deficiency.

Types of NTDs

Spina bifida occulta, meningocele, encephalocele, myelomeningocele, anencephaly, caudal regression syndrome, dermal sinus, tethered cord, syringomyelia, diastematomyelia, lipoma, iniencephaly.

Spina bifida occulta

Midline defect of vertebral bodies without protrusion of spinal cord or meninges; usually asymptomatic and not of consequence.

Craniorachischisis

Rare malformation with skull and spinal bone defects; brain and nerves exposed; may have other defects like imperforate anus.

Meningocele

Meninges herniate through vertebral arches or sacrum; spinal cord normal. Fluctuant midline mass that may transilluminate. Surgery may be delayed in asymptomatic cases with normal neuro findings and skin covering.

Myelomeningocele

Most common in lumbosacral region; sac-like cystic structure with neural tissue; 80% develop hydrocephalus with type II Chiari malformation.

Anencephaly

Large defect of calvarium, meninges, and scalp; associated with rudimentary brain due to failure of closure of rostral neuropore.

Iniencephaly

Retroflexion of head with occipital and upper spine defects, nearly absent neck; defect can range from acrania to minimal defect.

Prenatal diagnosis

Detailed ultrasound, MSAFP (maternal serum α-fetoprotein), amniotic fluid acetylcholinesterase (AChE).

Prevention

0.4 mg folic acid daily for all women of childbearing age; 4 mg daily for high-risk women (prior affected child).

Risk of recurrence

3-4% after 1 affected child; 10% after 2 affected children.

Treatment

Surgery for defect; VP shunt if hydrocephalus present. Open lesions should be closed within 24 hours. Antibiotics if infection is present.

questions.text: A male patient, aged 18, seeks medical attention due to an eye injury sustained while climbing a tree five days ago. The patient reports experiencing pain, sensitivity to light (photophobia), and redness in the affected eye for the past two days. Upon performing a slit-lamp examination, a lesion is observed as depicted below. Which of the following characteristics is associated with this particular condition?
questions.explanation:
Etiology
  • Causative organism: Aspergillus fumigatus >> Fusarium
  • Predisposing factor: Vegetative matter injury (trauma)

Clinical Features
  • SIGNS >> symptoms
  • Pain & Foreign Body Sensation
  • Watering/ Photophobia
  • Blurred Vision, Redness

Examination Findings
  • Corneal Ulcer: Greyish-white, dry, elevated, rolled-out margins
  • Pigmented Ulcer: Brownish, dematiaceous fungi
  • Feathery Extensions: Finger-like projections in stroma
  • Sterile Immune Ring: Yellow line of demarcation
  • Satellite Lesions (Option D): Small lesions around the main ulcer
  • Hypopyon: Large, immobile, non-sterile, even in small ulcer

Investigations
  • Corneal Scraping: For microbiological examination
  • Wet KOH Mount: Filamentous fungi or yeast-like fungi (Candida)
  • Culture: Sabouraud's agar for fungal culture
  • PCR: For rapid identification of pathogens
  • Corneal Biopsy: For deep stromal abscess or negative cultures

Treatment
  • Topical Antifungal Agents: Natamycin 5%, Voriconazole, Amphotericin-B, Nystatin
  • Oral Antifungal Agents: Ketoconazole, Voriconazole (for severe ulcers)
  • Surgical Management:
    • Repeated Scraping: Removal of necrotic material
    • Cauterization Options: Carbolic acid (100%), Trichloroacetic acid (10%–20%), Povidone-iodine (5%)
    • Therapeutic Keratoplasty: Corneal transplantation

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 5-year-old girl presenting with decreased best corrected visual acuity in the right eye after a school vision screening revealed diminution of acuity in the right eye without any examination findings of the eye and visual pathway?
questions.explanation:
Type

Cause

Key Features

Strabismic Amblyopia

The brain suppresses input from one eye due to constant squint (strabismus).

Common cause; underdevelopment of vision in the deviated eye.

Stimulus Deprivation Amblyopia

Hindered vision due to obstruction from early life (e.g., congenital cataracts, ptosis, dense central corneal opacity).

Lack of visual stimulation affects normal development.

Anisometropic Amblyopia

A significant difference in refractive error between eyes.

The brain favours the clearer eye, leading to amblyopia in the other.

Ametropic Amblyopia

High uncorrected refractive errors in both eyes.

Bilateral; is less severe compared to other types.

Meridional Amblyopia

Uncorrected astigmatism affecting specific visual meridians.

Affects one or both eyes depending on the astigmatism degree.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 7-year-old boy who showed a white pupillary reflex and underwent enucleation, with histopathological examination showing Flexner Wintersteiner rosettes?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Presentation
  • Leukocoria (60%)
  • Strabismus (20%)
  • Painful red eye (7%)
  • Poor vision (5%)
  • Asymptomatic (3%)

Fundus Examination
  • White, elevated mass in the retina
  • Can be endophytic, exophytic, or mixed growth

Imaging
  • CT scan: Calcification in 90% of cases
  • MRI: Better for evaluating optic nerve and extraocular extension
  • Ultrasound: Useful for initial screening

Histopathology
  • Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific): These are composed of an ‘empty’ lumen surrounded by columnar cells
  • Homer-Wright rosettes: These are pseudo-rosettes and consist of cells surrounding a central lumen made up of their processes
  • Undifferentiated tumor cells
  • Areas of necrosis and calcification

Genetic Testing
  • RB1 gene mutation on chromosome 13q14

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a man of 45 years who arrives at the emergency department with an abrupt loss of vision and experiencing painful movements of the eye? Upon examination, a relative afferent pupillary defect is observed in the affected eye. Further visual field testing demonstrates a central scotoma in the same eye.
questions.explanation:
Classification of Optic neuritis:

 

Papillitis

Retrobulbar Neuritis

Neuroretinitis (Option D)

Site

Optic disc

Optic nerve behind the eyeball.

Optic disc and surrounding retina in the macular area.

Characteristic features
  • Fundoscopy reveals a blurred disc margin due to leakage and increased capillary permeability, edematous and hyperaemic disc, and physiological cup is obliterated.
  • Pain on eye elevation
  • RAPD (relative afferent pupillary defect) is observed.
  • Fundoscopic examination typically reveals normal optic disc, at least initially, which is why the classic phrase, “the patient sees nothing, and the doctor sees nothing” is often used to describe retrobulbar neuritis.
  • A macular star is seen in fundoscopy (accumulation of lipids).
  • Optic atrophy present

Clinical features
  • Visual loss: Monocular sudden, progressive and profound visual loss is the hallmark of acute optic neuritis.
  • Dark adaptation may be lowered.
  • Visual obscuration in bright light is a typical symptom of acute optic neuritis.
  • Impairment of color vision is always present in optic neuritis.
  • Uhthoff's symptom: Episodic transient obscuration of vision on exertion and on exposure to heat, which recovers on resting or moving away from the heat, occurs in patients with isolated optic neuritis.
  • Pulfrich's phenomenon: Depth perception may be impaired, particularly for the moving object.
  • Visual acuity is usually reduced markedly.
  • Visual field changes: The most common field defect in optic neuritis is a relative central or centrocecal scotoma.
  • Contrast sensitivity is impaired.

Management of Optic neuritis:

Treatment

Indications

Details

Conservative management

(Observation and Monitoring)
  • Mild symptoms
  • Known history of similar episodes
  • Many cases improve spontaneously.
  • Suitable for mild symptoms but not recommended for severe cases or first episodes.

High-Dose Corticosteroids
  • Severe vision loss
  • No history of previous episodes
  • MRI evidence of demyelination
  • Intravenous methylprednisolone (1 g daily for 3 days) followed by oral prednisolone taper as established by the ONTT trial (Optic Neuritis Treatment Trial).

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a patient who wears contact lenses and has been experiencing eye watering, redness, and a sensation of having a foreign object in the eye for the last two months?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Specific allergic inflammation affecting the superior tarsal conjunctiva.

Etiology

  • Soft hydrophilic contact lenses
  • Protruding suture ends
  • Ocular prostheses

Underlying Mechanism

Hypersensitivity reactions (types I and IV)

Symptoms

  • Itching/ Watering
  • Foreign body sensation
  • Occasionally blurred vision

Signs

  • Conjunctival congestion predominantly in the upper palpebral region
  • Large polygonal papillae on superior tarsal conjunctiva
  • Macropapillae (0.3-1.0 mm) and giant papillae (1-2 mm)

Management

  • Discontinue soft contact lenses, remove offending sutures, clean and polish ocular prosthesis; replace with biocompatible material (e.g., Biocoat).
  • Ancillary therapy: Mast cell stabilizers (e.g., lodoxamide, cromolyn sodium, olopatadine) along with artificial tears, antihistaminic drops, and decongestants.

questions.text: Which investigation is most suitable for localizing a foreign body in the eye of an industrial worker admitted to the hospital due to an eye injury caused by cutting stone with a hammer and iron chisel?
questions.explanation:
Definition
  • An IOFB is a foreign object that penetrates the eye and remains lodged inside. It is a serious injury that can result in permanent vision loss.

Common Types of IOFBs
  • Metallic (90% of cases): Iron, steel.
  • Others: Glass, stone, lead pellets, copper, aluminium, plastic, wood.

Foreign Body Reactions
  • Inorganic Materials: Glass, plastic are inert; lead, aluminium, copper cause inflammatory responses.
  • Organic Materials: Wood causes giant cell reactions and granulomatous inflammation.

Diagnosis
  • Detailed History: Understand injury mechanism for IOFB type.
  • Ocular Examination:
    • Slit-lamp examination
    • Gonioscopy
    • Ophthalmoscopy (back of the eye)
  • Signs:
    • Subconjunctival hemorrhage
    • Corneal scars/ Iris holes
    • Opaque tracks in the lens/ IOFB in vitreous or retina
  • Investigations:
    • X-rays: Less common; CT is preferred. (Option C)
    • Ultrasonography: B-mode USG locates both radiopaque and non-radiopaque IOFBs. (Option A)
    • CT Scan: Investigation of choice/ Gold standard for detailed cross-sectional images.(Option B)
    • MRI: Contra-indicated in case of metal foreign bodies (Option D)

Treatment
  • IOFB Removal: Essential except for inert, sterile IOFBs not affecting vision or if removal is too risky.
    • Magnetic IOFBs: Removed using a handheld electromagnet.
    • Non-magnetic IOFBs: Requires specialized procedures.
  • Removal Methods:
    • Anterior Chamber:
      • Corneal incision, avoiding central cornea.
      • Magnetic IOFBs: Handheld magnet.
      • Non-magnetic IOFBs: Specialized forceps.
    • Iris: Sector iridectomy for IOFBs in the iris.
    • Lens: Extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) with or without lens removal.
    • Vitreous and Retina: Pars plana vitrectomy

Post-Removal Management
  • Topical/systemic antibiotics for infection prevention.
  • Topical corticosteroids to reduce inflammation.
  • Cycloplegic agents (e.g., atropine) for pupil dilation and pain relief.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is accompanied by his wife to the Neurology OPD. His wife expressed concern about her husband's condition and they were directed to this facility by a local doctor. According to the doctor's note, the patient is unable to repeat spoken words but can comprehend them and respond appropriately by nodding. The patient also experiences difficulty in naming people and writing. The doctor referred the patient to a specialized facility for a CT brain scan. As the intern on duty, you would inform the Chief Medical Officer (CMO) that this condition could be indicative of a brain lesion in which specific area?
questions.explanation:
Aphasia Type

Area Affected

Features

Broca's Aphasia

Left frontal lobe (Broca's area)

Non-fluent speech, difficulty forming sentences, good comprehension, and poor writing/speech output.

Wernicke's Aphasia

Left temporal lobe (Wernicke's area)

Fluent speech with normal grammar, but speech is nonsensical or meaningless, poor comprehension.

Conduction Aphasia

Arcuate fasciculus (connecting Broca's and Wernicke's areas)

Difficulty repeating words or phrases, fluent speech with errors, good comprehension.

Global Aphasia

Widespread damage to left hemisphere (Broca's, Wernicke's, and arcuate fasciculus)

Severe communication deficits: non-fluent speech, poor comprehension, and inability to repeat.

questions.text: Which of the following lenses would be recommended to correct myopia?
questions.explanation:
General measures
  • Balanced diet
  • Visual hygiene: Posture correction, adequate illumination, reducing usage of video display units (VDUs)

Optical

Concave lenses are prescribed: Spectacles/ contact lenses (Option B)

Surgical

Radial Keratotomy (RK):

  • Used for low to moderate myopia (2-6 D).
  • No longer recommended due to the advent of safer procedures like LASIK.

 

Photorefractive Keratectomy (PRK):

  • It uses an excimer laser to reshape the cornea by removing a thin corneal layer.
  • Suitable for correcting myopia up to -6 D.

 

Refractive Lenticule Extraction (SMILE):

  • A minimally invasive laser procedure where a small lenticule is removed to reshape the cornea.
  • Effective for myopia up to -10 D, with or without astigmatism.

 

Phakic Intraocular Lens (IOL) Implantation:

  • Implantable lens placed without removing the natural lens.
  • Best for myopia exceeding -8 D, especially in patients unsuitable for laser surgery.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man was referred to the surgery OPD from the infertility clinic. On palpation, a bag of worms sensation was felt with dilated veins. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Varicocele

Common Occurrence
  • More common in tall, thin young men
  • More frequent on the left side but can be bilateral

Causes
  • Idiopathic
  • Absence or incompetent valve at the junction of the left testicular vein and left renal vein
  • Perpendicular entry of the left testicular vein into the left renal vein
  • Left-sided renal cell carcinoma causing blockage of the left testicular vein

Effects
  • Increased temperature in the scrotum, depressing spermatogenesis and causing infertility

Symptoms
  • Swelling at the root of the scrotum
  • Dragging pain in the groin and scrotum
  • "Bag of worms" feeling
  • Impulse on coughing
  • Swelling reduces on lying down (except in renal cell carcinoma)

Investigations
  • Venous Doppler of the scrotum and groin
  • Ultrasound of the abdomen to check for kidney tumours
  • Semen analysis

Treatment

  • Palomo's Operation: Suprainguinal extraperitoneal ligation of the testicular vein
  • Ligation of veins
  • Excision of veins

questions.text: Pressure greater than __ mm of Hg causes pressure sores.:

What would be the best treatment option for a patient who has been diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma and has a tumour measuring 10 cm in size, located at the lower part of the kidney, and has negative regional lymph nodes?
questions.explanation:
Treatment of RCC: RCCs are radio and chemo-resistant.

Surgical Management:

Partial Nephrectomy: Involves removing only the tumour while preserving the remainder of the kidney.

Indications:

  • T1 Disease(<7cm)
  • Restricted to poles
  • RCC in solitary functioning kidney

Radical Nephrectomy: Involves removal of the kidney with Gerota’s fascia, para-aortic nodes, and ureter up to the pelvic brim.

Indications: Larger tumours or when partial nephrectomy is not feasible

Ablative Techniques

Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA) and Cryoablation involve destroying the tumour using extreme temperatures.

Indications:

  • Patients who are not surgical candidates
  • Patients with small tumours (T1a lesions) (usually <4 cm).

Systemic Therapy

(For advanced/ metastatic disease)

Targeted Therapy

  • Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., sunitinib, pazopanib)
  • mTOR inhibitors (e.g., everolimus)

Immunotherapy: Immune checkpoint inhibitors (e.g., nivolumab)
